column1: bhrāmarī ganḍamālī ca śvitry atho piśunas tathā / unmatto 'ndhaś ca varjyāḥ syur vedanindaka eva ca //
column2: An epileptic man, who suffers from scrofulous swellings of the glands, one afflicted with white leprosy, an informer, a madman, a blind man, and he who cavils at the Veda must (all) be avoided.

column1: hastigo'śvoṣṭradamako nakṣatrair yaś ca jīvati / pakṣiṇāṃ poṣako yaś ca yuddhācāryas tathaiva ca //
column2: A trainer of elephants, oxen, horses, or camels, he who subsists by astrology, a bird-fancier, and he who teaches the use of arms,

column1: srotasāṃ bhedako yaś ca teṣāṃ cāvaraṇe rataḥ / gṛhasaṃveśako dūto vṛkṣāropaka eva ca //
column2: He who diverts water-courses, and he who delights in obstructing them, an architect, a messenger, and he who plants trees (for money),

column1: śvakrīḍī śyenajīvī ca kanyādūṣaka eva ca / hiṃsro vṛṣalavṛttiś ca gaṇānāṃ caiva yājakaḥ // ācārahīnaḥ klībaś ca nityaṃ yācanakas tathā / kṛṣijīvī ślīpadī ca sadbhir nindita eva ca // aurabhriko māhiṣikaḥ parapūrvāpatis tathā / pretaniryāpakaś caiva varjanīyāḥ prayatnataḥ //
column2: A breeder of sporting-dogs, a falconer, one who defiles maidens, he who delights in injuring living creatures, he who gains his subsistence from Sudras, and he who offers sacrifices to the Ganas, He who does not follow the rule of conduct, a (man destitute of energy like a) eunuch, one who constantly asks (for favours), he who lives by agriculture, a club-footed man, and he who is censured by virtuous men, A shepherd, a keeper of buffaloes, the husband of a remarried woman, and a carrier of dead bodies, (all these) must be carefully avoided.

column1: etān vigarhitācārān apāṅkteyān dvijādhamān / dvijātipravaro vidvān ubhayatra vivarjayet //
column2: A Brahmana who knows (the sacred law) should shun at (sacrifices) both (to the gods and to the manes) these lowest of twice-born men, whose conduct is reprehensible, and who are unworthy (to sit) in the company (at a repast).

column1: brāhmaṇo tv anadhīyānas tṛṇāgnir iva śāmyati / tasmai havyaṃ na dātavyaṃ na hi bhasmani hūyate //
column2: As a fire of dry grass is (unable to consume the offerings and is quickly) extinguished, even so (is it with) an unlearned Brahmana; sacrificial food must not be given to him, since it (would be) offered in ashes.

column1: apāṅktadāne yo dātur bhavaty ūrdhvaṃ phalodayaḥ / daive haviṣi pitrye vā taṃ pravaksyāmy aśeṣataḥ //
column2: I will fully declare what result the giver obtains after death, if he gives food, destined for the gods or manes, to a man who is unworthy to sit in the company.

column1: avratair yad dvijair bhuktaṃ parivetrādibhis tathā / apāṅkteyair yad anyaiś ca tad vai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate //
column2: The Rakshasas, indeed, consume (the food) eaten by Brahmanas who have not fulfilled the vow of studentship, by a Parivettri and so forth, and by other men not admissible into the company.

column1: dārāgnihotrasaṃyogaṃ kurute yo 'graje sthite / parivettā sa vijñeyaḥ parivittis tu pūrvajaḥ //
column2: He must be considered as a Parivettri who marries or begins the performance of the Agnihotra before his elder brother, but the latter as a Parivitti.

column1: parivittiḥ parivettā yayā ca parividyate / sarve te narakaṃ yānti dātṛyājakapañcamāḥ //
column2: The elder brother who marries after the younger, the younger brother who marries before the elder, the female with whom such a marriage is contracted, he who gives her away, and the sacrificing priest, as the fifth, all fall into hell.

column1: bhrātur mṛtasya bhāryāyāṃ yo 'nurajyeta kāmataḥ / dharmeṇāpi niyuktāyāṃ sa jñeyo didhiṣūpatiḥ //
column2: He who lasciviously dallies with the widow of a deceased brother, though she be appointed (to bear a child by him) in accordance with the sacred law, must be known to be a Didhishupati.

column1: paradāreṣu jāyete dvau sutau kuṇḍagolakau / patyau jīvati kuṇḍaḥ syān mṛte bhartari golakaḥ //
column2: Two (kinds of) sons, a Kunda and a Golaka, are born by wives of other men; (he who is born) while the husband lives, will be a Kunda, and (he who is begotten) after the husband's death, a Golaka.

column1: tau tu jātau parakṣetre prāṇinau pretya ceha ca / dattāni havyakavyāni nāśayanti pradāyinām //
column2: But those two creatures, who are born of wives of other men, cause to the giver the loss (of the rewards), both in this life and after death, for the food sacred to gods or manes which has been given (to them).

column1: apāṅktyo yāvataḥ paṅktyān bhuñjānān anupaśyati / tāvatāṃ na phalaṃ tatra dātā prāpnoti bāliśaḥ //
column2: The foolish giver (of a funeral repast) does not reap the reward for as many worthy guests as a man, inadmissible into company, can look on while they are feeding.

column1: vīkṣyāndho navateḥ kāṇaḥ ṣaṣṭeḥ śvitrī śatasya tu / pāparogī sahasrasya dātur nāśayate phalam //
column2: A blind man by his presence causes to the giver (of the feast) the loss of the reward for ninety (guests), a one-eyed man for sixty, one who suffers from white leprosy for a hundred, and one punished by a (terrible) disease for a thousand.

column1: yāvataḥ saṃspṛśed aṅgair brāhmaṇāñ śūdrayājakaḥ / tāvatāṃ na bhaved dātuḥ phalaṃ dānasya paurtikam //
column2: The giver (of a Sraddha) loses the reward, due for such a non-sacrificial gift, for as many Brahmanas as a (guest) who sacrifices for Sudras may touch (during the meal) with his limbs.

column1: vedavic cāpi vipro 'sya lobhāt kṛtvā pratigraham / vināśaṃ vrajati kṣipram āmapātram ivāmbhasi // somavikrayiṇe viṣṭhā bhiṣaje pūyaśoṇitam / naṣṭaṃ devalake dattam apratiṣṭhaṃ tu vārdhuṣau // yat tu vāṇijake dattaṃ neha nāmutra tad bhavet / bhasmanīva hutaṃ dravyaṃ tathā paunarbhave dvije //
column2: And if a Brahmana, though learned in the Veda, accepts through covetousness a gift from such (a man), he will quickly perish, like a vessel of unburnt clay in water.180 (Food) given to a seller of Soma becomes ordure, (that given) to a physician pus and blood, but (that presented) to a temple-priest is lost, and (that given) to a usurer finds no place (in the world of the gods). What has been given to a Brahmana who lives by trade that is not (useful) in this world and the next, and (a present) to a Brahmana born of a remarried woman (resembles) an oblation thrown into ashes.

column1: itareṣu tv apāṅktyeṣu yathoddiṣṭeṣv asādhuṣu / medo'sṛṅmāṃsamajjāsthi vadanty annaṃ manīṣiṇaḥ //
column2: But the wise declare that the food which (is offered) to other unholy, inadmissible men, enumerated above, (is turned into) adipose secretions, blood, flesh, marrow, and bone.

column1: apāṅktyopahatā paṅktiḥ pāvyate yair dvijottamaiḥ / tān nibodhata kārtsnyena dvijāgryān paṅktipāvanān //
column2: Now hear by what chief of twice-born men a company defiled by (the presence of) unworthy (guests) is purified, and the full (description of) the Brahmanas who sanctify a company.

column1: agryāḥ sarveṣu vedeṣu sarvapravacaneṣu ca / śrotriyānvayajāś caiva vijñeyāḥ paṅktipāvanāḥ //
column2: Those men must be considered as the sanctifiers of a company who are most learned in all the Vedas and in all the Angas, and who are the descendants of Srotriyas.

column1: triṇāciketaḥ pañcāgnis trisuparṇaḥ ṣaḍaṅgavit / brahmadeyātmasantāno jyeṣṭhasāmaga eva ca //
column2: A Trinakiketa, one who keeps five sacred fires, a Trisuparna, one who is versed in the six Angas, the son of a woman married according to the Brahma rite, one who sings the Gyeshthasaman,

column1: vedārthavit pravaktā ca brahmacārī sahasradaḥ / śatāyuś caiva vijñeyā brāhmaṇāḥ paṅktipāvanāḥ //
column2: One who knows the meaning of the Veda, and he who expounds it, a student, one who has given a thousand (cows), and a centenarian must be considered as Brahmanas who sanctify a company.

column1: pūrvedyur aparedyur vā śrāddhakarmaṇy upasthite / nimantrayeta tryavarān samyag viprān yathoditān //
column2: On the day before the Sraddha-rite is performed, or on the day when it takes place, let him invite with due respect at least three Brahmanas, such as have been mentioned above.

column1: nimantrito dvijaḥ pitrye niyatātmā bhavet sadā / na ca chandāṃsy adhīyīta yasya śrāddhaṃ ca tad bhavet //
column2: A Brahmana who has been invited to a (rite) in honour of the manes shall always control himself and not recite the Veda, and he who performs the Sraddha (must act in the same manner).

column1: nimantritān hi pitara upatiṣṭhanti tān dvijān / vāyuvac cānugacchanti tathāsīnān upāsate //
column2: For the manes attend the invited Brahmanas, follow them (when they walk) like the wind, and sit near them when they are seated.

column1: ketitas tu yathānyāyaṃ havye kavye dvijottamaḥ / kathaṃ cid apy atikrāman pāpaḥ sūkaratāṃ vrajet // āmantritas tu yaḥ śrāddhe vṛśalyā saha modate / dātur yad duṣkṛtaṃ kiṃ cit tat sarvaṃ pratipadyate //
column2: But a Brahmana who, being duly invited to a rite in honour of the gods or of the manes, in any way breaks (the appointment), becomes guilty (of a crime), and (in his next birth) a hog. But he who, being invited to a Sraddha, dallies with a Sudra woman, takes upon himself all the sins which the giver (of the feast) committed.

column1: akrodhanāḥ śaucaparāḥ satataṃ brahmacāriṇaḥ / nyastaśastrā mahābhāgāḥ pitaraḥ pūrvadevatāḥ //
column2: The manes are primeval deities, free from anger, careful of purity, ever chaste, averse from strife, and endowed with great virtues.

column1: yasmād utpattir eteṣāṃ sarveṣām apy aśeṣataḥ / ye ca yair upacaryāḥ syur niyamais tān nibodhata //
column2: Now learn fully from whom all these (manes derive) their origin, and with what ceremonies they ought to be worshipped.

column1: manor hairaṇyagarbhasya ye marīcyādayaḥ sutāḥ / teṣām ṛṣīṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ putrāḥ pitṛgaṇāḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: The (various) classes of the manes are declared to be the sons of all those sages, Mariki and the rest, who are children of Manu, the son of Hiranyagarbha.

column1: virāṭsutāḥ somasadaḥ sādhyānāṃ pitaraḥ smṛtāḥ / agniṣvāttāś ca devānāṃ mārīcā lokaviśrutāḥ //
column2: The Somasads, the sons of Virag, are stated to be the manes of the Sadhyas, and the Agnishvattas, the children of Mariki, are famous in the world (as the manes) of the gods.

column1: daityadānavayakṣāṇāṃ gandharvoragarakṣasām / suparṇakinnarāṇāṃ ca smṛtā barhiṣado 'trijāḥ //
column2: The Barhishads, born of Atri, are recorded to be (the manes) of the Daityas, Danavas, Yakshas, Gandharvas, Snake-deities,Rakshasas, Suparnas, and a Kimnaras,

column1: somapā nāma viprāṇāṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ havirbhujaḥ / vaiśyānām ājyapā nāma śūdrāṇāṃ tu sukālinaḥ //
column2: The Somapas those of the Brahmanas, the Havirbhugs those of the Kshatriyas, the Agyapas those of the Vaisyas, but the Sukalins those of the Sudras.

column1: somapās tu kaveḥ putrā haviṣmanto 'ṅgiraḥsutāḥ / pulastyasyājyapāḥ putrā vasiṣṭhasya sukālinaḥ //
column2: The Somapas are the sons of Kavi (Bhrigu), the Havishmats the children of Angiras, the Agyapas the offspring of Pulastya, but the Sukalins (the issue) of Vasishtha.

column1: agnidagdhānagnidagdhān kāvyān barhiṣadas tathā / agniṣvāttāṃś ca saumyāṃś ca viprāṇām eva nirdiśet //
column2: One should know that (other classes), the Agnidagdhas, the Anagnidagdhas, the Kavyas, the Barhishads, the Agnishvattas, and the Saumyas, are (the manes) of the Brahmanas alone.

column1: ya ete tu gaṇā mukhyāḥ pitṝṇāṃ parikīrtitāḥ / teṣām apīha vijñeyaṃ putrapautram anantakam //
column2: But know also that there exist in this (world) countless sons and grandsons of those chief classes of manes which have been enumerated.

column1: ṛṣibhyaḥ pitaro jātāḥ pitṛbhyo devamānavāḥ / devebhyas tu jagat sarvaṃ caraṃ sthāṇv anupūrvaśaḥ //
column2: From the sages sprang the manes, from the manes the gods and the Danavas, but from the gods the whole world, both the movable and the immovable in due order.

column1: rājatair bhājanair eṣām atho vā rajatānvitaiḥ / vāry api śraddhayā dattam akṣayāyopakalpate //
column2: Even water offered with faith (to the manes) in vessels made of silver or adorned with silver, produces endless (bliss).

column1: daivakāryād dvijātīnāṃ pitṛkāryaṃ viśiṣyate / daivaṃ hi pitṛkāryasya pūrvam āpyāyanaṃ smṛtam //
column2: For twice-born men the rite in honour of the manes is more important than the rite in honour of the gods; for the offering to the gods which precedes (the Sraddhas), has been declared to be a means of fortifying (the latter).

column1: teṣām ārakṣabhūtaṃ tu pūrvaṃ daivaṃ niyojayet / raksāṃsi vipralumpanti śrāddham ārakṣavarjitam //
column2: Let him first invite a (Brahmana) in honour of the gods as a protection for the (offering to the manes); for the Rakshasas destroy a funeral sacrifice which is left without such a protection.

column1: daivādyantaṃ tad īheta pitrādyantaṃ na tad bhavet / pitrādyantaṃ tv īhamānaḥ kṣipraṃ naśyati sānvayaḥ //
column2: Let him make (the Sraddha) begin and end with (a rite) in honour of the gods; it shall not begin and end with a (rite) to the manes; for he who makes it begin and end with a (rite) in honour of the manes, soon perishes together with his progeny.

column1: śuciṃ deśaṃ viviktaṃ ca gomayenopalepayet / dakṣināpravaṇaṃ caiva prayatnenopapādayet //
column2: Let him smear a pure and secluded place with cowdung, and carefully make it sloping towards the south.

column1: avakāśeṣu cokṣeṣu jalatīreṣu caiva hi / vivikteṣu ca tuṣyanti dattena pitaraḥ sadā //
column2: The manes are always pleased with offerings made in open, naturally pure places, on the banks of rivers, and in secluded spots.

column1: āsaneṣūpakḷpteṣu barhiṣmatsu pṛthakpṛthak / upaspṛṣṭodakān samyag viprāṃs tān upaveśayet // upaveśya tu tān viprān āsaneṣv ajugupsitān / gandhamālyaiḥ surabhibhir arcayed daivapūrvakam // teṣām udakam ānīya sapavitrāṃs tilān api / agnau kuryād anujñāto brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇaiḥ saha //
column2: The (sacrificer) shall make the (invited) Brahmanas, who have duly performed their ablutions, sit down on separate, prepared seats, on which blades of Kusa grass have been placed. Having placed those blameless Brahmanas on their seats, he shall honour them with fragrant garlands and perfumes, beginning with (those who are invited in honour of) the gods. Having presented to them water, sesamum grains, and blades of Kusa grass, the Brahmana (sacrificer) shall offer (oblations) in the sacred fire, after having received permission (to do so) from (all) the Brahmana (guests) conjointly.

column1: agneḥ somayamābhyāṃ ca kṛtvāpyāyanam āditaḥ / havirdānena vidhivat paścāt saṃtarpayet pitṝn //
column2: Having first, according to the rule, performed, as a means of protecting (the Sraddha), oblations to Agni, to Soma, and to Yama, let him afterwards satisfy the manes by a gift of sacrificial food.

column1: agnyabhāve tu viprasya pāṇāv evopapādayet / yo hy agniḥ sa dvijo viprair mantradarśibhir ucyate //
column2: But if no (sacred) fire (is available), he shall place (the offerings) into the hand of a Brahmana; for Brahmanas who know the sacred texts declare, 'What fire is, even such is a Brahmana.'

column1: akrodhanān suprasādān vadanty etān purātanān / lokasyāpyāyane yuktān śrāddhadevān dvijottamān //
column2: They (also) call those first of twice-born men the ancient deities of the funeral sacrifice, free from anger, easily pleased, employed in making men prosper.

column1: apasavyam agnau kṛtvā sarvam āvṛtya vikramam / apasavyena hastena nirvaped udakaṃ bhuvi //
column2: After he has performed (the oblations) in the fire, (and) the whole series of ceremonies in such a manner that they end in the south, let him sprinkle water with his right hand on the spot (where the cakes are to be placed).

column1: trīṃs tu tasmād dhaviḥśeṣāt piṇḍān kṛtvā samāhitaḥ / audakenaiva vidhinā nirvaped dakṣiṇāmukhaḥ //
column2: But having made three cakes out of the remainder of that sacrificial food, he must, concentrating his mind and turning towards the south, place them on (Kusa grass) exactly in the same manner in which (he poured out the libations of) water.

column1: nyupya piṇḍāṃs tatas tāṃs tu prayato vidhipūrvakam / teṣu darbheṣu taṃ hastaṃ nirmṛjyāl lepabhāginām //
column2: Having offered those cakes according to the (prescribed) rule, being pure, let him wipe the same hand with (the roots of) those blades of Kusa grass for the sake of the (three ancestors) who partake of the wipings (lepa).

column1: ācamyodakparāvṛtya trir āyamya śanair asūn / ṣaḍ ṛtūṃś ca namaskuryāt pitṝn eva ca mantravat //
column2: Having (next) sipped water, turned round (towards the north), and thrice slowly suppressed his breath, (the sacrificer) who knows the sacred texts shall worship (the guardian deities of) the six seasons and the manes.

column1: udakaṃ ninayec cheṣaṃ śanaiḥ piṇḍāntike punaḥ / avajighrec ca tān piṇḍān yathānyuptān samāhitaḥ //
column2: Let him gently pour out the remainder of the water near the cakes, and, with fixed attention, smell those cakes, in the order in which they were placed (on the ground).

column1: piṇḍebhyas tv alpikāṃ mātrāṃ samādāyānupūrvaśaḥ / tān eva viprān āsīnān vidhivat pūrvam āśayet //
column2: But taking successively very small portions from the cakes, he shall make those seated Brahmana eat them, in accordance with the rule, before (their dinner).

column1: dhriyamāṇe tu pitari pūrveṣām eva nirvapet / vipravad vāpi taṃ śrāddhe svakaṃ pitaram āśayet //
column2: But if the (sacrificer's) father is living, he must offer (the cakes) to three remoter (ancestors); or he may also feed his father at the funeral sacrifice as (one of the) Brahmana (guests).

column1: pitā yasya nivṛttaḥ syāj jīvec cāpi pitāmahaḥ / pituḥ sa nāma saṅkīrtya kīrtayet prapitāmaham //
column2: But he whose father is dead, while his grandfather lives, shall, after pronouncing his father's name, mention (that of) his great-grandfather.

column1: pitāmaho vā tacchrāddhaṃ bhuñjītety abravīn manuḥ / kāmaṃ vā samanujñātaḥ svayam eva samācaret //
column2: Manu has declared that either the grandfather may eat at that Sraddha (as a guest), or (the grandson) having received permission, may perform it, as he desires.

column1: teṣāṃ dattvā tu hasteṣu sapavitraṃ tilodakam / tatpiṇḍāgraṃ prayaccheta svadhaiṣām astv iti bruvan // pāṇibhyāṃ tūpasaṃgṛhya svayam annasya vardhitam / viprāntike pitṝn dhyāyan śanakair upanikṣipet //
column2: Having poured water mixed with sesamum, in which a blade of Kusa grass has been placed, into the hands of the (guests), he shall give (to each) that (above-mentioned) portion of the cake, saying, 'To those, Svadha!' But carrying (the vessel) filled with food with both hands, the (sacrificer) himself shall gently place it before the Brahmanas, meditating on the manes.

column1: ubhayor hastayor muktaṃ yad annam upanīyate / tad vipralumpanty asurāḥ sahasā duṣṭacetasaḥ //
column2: The malevolent Asuras forcibly snatch away that food which is brought without being held with both hands.

column1: guṇāṃś ca sūpaśākādyān payo dadhi ghṛtaṃ madhu / vinyaset prayataḥ pūrvaṃ bhūmāv eva samāhitaḥ //
column2: Let him, being pure and attentive, carefully place on the ground the seasoning (for the rice), such as broths and pot herbs, sweet and sour milk, and honey,

column1: bhakṣyaṃ bhojyaṃ ca vividhaṃ mūlāni ca phalāni ca / hṛdyāni caiva māṃsāni pānāni surabhīṇi ca //
column2: (As well as) various (kinds of) hard food which require mastication, and of soft food, roots, fruits, savoury meat, and fragrant drinks.

column1: upanīya tu tat sarvaṃ śanakaiḥ susamāhitaḥ / pariveṣayeta prayato guṇān sarvān pracodayan //
column2: All this he shall present (to his guests), being pure and attentive, successively invite them to partake of each (dish), proclaiming its qualities.

column1: nāsram āpātayej jātu na kupyen nānṛtaṃ vadet / na pādena spṛśed annaṃ na caitad avadhūnayet //
column2: Let him on no account drop a tear, become angry or utter an untruth, nor let him touch the food with his foot nor violently shake it.

column1: asraṃ gamayati pretān kopo 'rīn anṛtaṃ śunaḥ / pādasparśas tu rakṣāṃsi duṣkṛtīn avadhūnanam //
column2: A tear sends the (food) to the Pretas, anger to his enemies, a falsehood to the dogs, contact with his foot to the Rakshasas, a shaking to the sinners.

column1: yad yad roceta viprebhyas tat tad dadyād amatsaraḥ / brahmodyāś ca kathāḥ kuryāt pitṝṇām etad īpsitam //
column2: Whatever may please the Brahmanas, let him give without grudging it; let him give riddles from the Veda, for that is agreeable to the manes.

column1: svādhyāyaṃ śrāvayet pitrye dharmaśāstrāṇi caiva hi / ākhyānānītihāsāṃś ca purāṇāni khilāni ca //
column2: At a (sacrifice in honour) of the manes, he must let (his guests) hear the Veda, the Institutes of the sacred law, legends, tales, Puranas, and Khilas.

column1: harṣayed brāhmaṇāṃs tuṣṭo bhojayec ca śanaiḥśanaiḥ / annādyenāsakṛc caitān guṇaiś ca paricodayet //
column2: Himself being delighted, let him give delight to the Brahmanas, cause them to partake gradually and slowly (of each dish), and repeatedly invite (them to eat) by (offering) the food and (praising) its qualities.

column1: vratastham api dauhitraṃ śrāddhe yatnena bhojayet / kutapaṃ cāsanaṃ dadyāt tilaiś ca vikiren mahīm //
column2: Let him eagerly entertain at a funeral sacrifice a daughter's son, though he be a student, and let him place a Nepal blanket on the on the seat (of each guest), scattering sesamum grains on the ground.

column1: trīṇi śrāddhe pavitrāṇi dauhitraḥ kutapas tilāḥ / trīṇi cātra praśaṃsanti śaucam akrodham atvarām //
column2: There are three means of sanctification, (to be used) at a Sraddha, a daughter's son, a Nepal blanket, and sesamum grains; and they recommend three (other things) for it, cleanliness, suppression of anger, and absence of haste.

column1: atyuṣṇaṃ sarvam annaṃ syād bhuñjīraṃs te ca vāgyatāḥ / na ca dvijātayo brūyur dātrā pṛṣṭā havirguṇān //
column2: All the food must be very hot, and the (guests) shall eat in silence; (even though) asked by the giver (of the feast), the Brahmanas shall not proclaim the qualities of the sacrificial food.

column1: yāvad uṣmā bhavaty annaṃ yāvad aśnanti vāgyatāḥ / pitaras tāvad aśnanti yāvan noktā havirguṇāḥ //
column2: As long as the food remains warm, as long as they eat in silence, as long as the qualities of the food are not proclaimed, so long the manes partake (of it).

column1: yad veṣṭitaśirā bhuṅkte yad bhuṅkte dakṣiṇāmukhaḥ / sopānatkaś ca yad bhuṅkte tad vai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate //
column2: What (a guest) eats, covering his head, what he eats with his face turned towards the south, what he eats with sandals on (his feet), that the Rakshasas consume.

column1: cāṇḍālaś ca varāhaś ca kukkuṭaḥ śvā tathaiva ca / rajasvalā ca ṣaṇḍhaś ca nekṣerann aśnato dvijān //
column2: A Kandala, a village pig, a cock, a dog, a menstruating woman, and a eunuch must not look at the Brahmanas while they eat.

column1: home pradāne bhojye ca yad ebhir abhivīkṣyate / daive haviṣi pitrye vā tad gacchaty ayathātatham //
column2: What (any of) these sees at a burnt-oblation, at a (solemn) gift, at a dinner (given to Brahmanas), or at any rite in honour of the gods and manes, that produces not the intended result.

column1: ghrāṇena sūkaro hanti pakṣavātena kukkuṭaḥ / śvā tu dṛṣṭinipātena sparśeṇāvaravarṇajaḥ //
column2: A boar makes (the rite) useless by inhaling the smell (of the offerings), a cock by the air of his wings, a dog by throwing his eye (on them), a low-caste man by touching (them).

column1: khañjo vā yadi vā kāṇo dātuḥ preṣyo 'pi vā bhavet / hīnātiriktagātro vā tam apy apanayet punaḥ //
column2: If a lame man, a one-eyed man, one deficient in a limb, or one with a redundant limb, be even the servant of the performer (of the Sraddha), he must be removed from that place (where the Sraddha is held).

column1: brāhmaṇaṃ bhikṣukaṃ vāpi bhojanārtham upasthitam / brāhmaṇair abhyanujñātaḥ śaktitaḥ pratipūjayet //
column2: To a Brahmana (householder), or to an ascetic who comes for food, he may, with the permission of (his) Brahmana (guests), show honour according to his ability.

column1: sārvavarṇikam annādyaṃ saṃnīyāplāvya vāriṇā / samutsṛjed bhuktavatām agrato vikiran bhuvi //
column2: Let him mix all the kinds of food together, sprinkle them with water and put them, scattering them (on Kusa grass), down on the ground in front of (his guests), when they have finished their meal.

column1: asaṃskṛtapramītānāṃ tyāgināṃ kulayoṣitām / ucchiṣṭaṃ bhāgadheyaṃ syād darbheṣu vikiraś ca yaḥ // uccheṣaṇāṃ bhūmigatam ajihmasyāśaṭhasya ca / dāsavargasya tat pitrye bhāgadheyaṃ pracakṣate //
column2: The remnant (in the dishes), and the portion scattered on Kusa grass, shall be the share of deceased (children) who received not the sacrament (of cremation) and of those who (unjustly) forsook noble wives. They declare the fragments which have fallen on the ground at a (Sraddha) to the manes, to be the share of honest, dutiful servants.

column1: āsapiṇḍakriyākarma dvijāteḥ saṃsthitasya tu / adaivaṃ bhojayec chrāddhaṃ piṇḍam ekaṃ ca nirvapet //
column2: But before the performance of the Sapindikarana, one must feed at the funeral sacrifice in honour of a (recently-) deceased Aryan (one Brahmana) without (making an offering) to the gods, and give one cake only.

column1: sahapiṇḍakriyāyāṃ tu kṛtāyām asya dharmataḥ / anayaivāvṛtā kāryaṃ piṇḍanirvapanaṃ sutaiḥ //
column2: But after the Sapindikarana of the (deceased father) has been performed according to the sacred law, the sons must offer the cakes with those ceremonies, (described above.)

column1: śrāddhaṃ bhuktvā ya ucchiṣṭaṃ vṛṣalāya prayacchati / sa mūḍho narakaṃ yāti kālasūtram avākśirāḥ //
column2: The foolish man who, after having eaten a Sraddha (-dinner), gives the leavings to a Sudra, falls headlong into the Kalasutra hell.

column1: śrāddhabhug vṛṣalītalpaṃ tad ahar yo 'dhigacchati / tasyāḥ purīṣe taṃ māsaṃ pitaras tasya śerate //
column2: If the partaker of a Sraddha (-dinner) enters on the same day the bed of a Sudra female, the manes of his (ancestors) will lie during that month in her ordure.

column1: pṛṣṭvā svaditam ity evaṃ tṛptān ācāmayet tataḥ / ācāntāṃś cānujānīyād abhito ramyatām iti //
column2: Having addressed the question, 'Have you dined well?' (to his guests), let him give water for sipping to them who are satisfied, and dismiss them, after they have sipped water, (with the words) 'Rest either (here or at home)!'

column1: svadhāstv ity eva taṃ brūyur brāhmaṇās tadanantaram / svadhākāraḥ parā hy āṣīḥ sarveṣu pitṛkarmasu //
column2: The Brahmana (guests) shall then answer him, 'Let there be Svadha;' for at all rites in honour of the manes the word Svadha is the highest benison.

column1: tato bhuktavatāṃ teṣām annaśeṣaṃ nivedayet / yathā brūyus tathā kuryād anujñātas tato dvijaiḥ //
column2: Next let him inform (his guests) who have finished their meal, of the food which remains; with the permission of the Brahmanas let him dispose (of that), as they may direct.

column1: pitrye svaditam ity eva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam / saṃpannam ity abhyudaye daive rucitam ity api // aparāhṇas tathā darbhā vāstusaṃpādanaṃ tilāḥ / sṛṣṭir mṛṣṭir dvijāś cāgryāḥ śrāddhakarmasu saṃpadaḥ //
column2: At a (Sraddha) in honour of the manes one must use (in asking of the guests if they are satisfied, the word) svaditam; at a Goshthi-sraddha, (the word) susrutam; at a Vriddhi-sraddha, (the word) sampannam; and at (a rite) in honour of the gods, (the word) rukitam. The afternoon, Kusa grass, the due preparation of the dwelling, sesamum grains, liberality, the careful preparation of the food, and (the company of) distinguished Brahmanas are true riches at all funeral sacrifices.

column1: darbhāḥ pavitraṃ pūrvāhṇo haviṣyāṇi ca sarvaśaḥ / pavitraṃ yac ca pūrvoktaṃ vijñeyā havyasaṃpadaḥ //
column2: Know that Kusa grass, purificatory (texts), the morning, sacrificial viands of all kinds, and those means of purification, mentioned above, are blessings at a sacrifice to the gods.

column1: munyannāni payaḥ somo māṃsaṃ yac cānupaskṛtam / aksāralavaṇaṃ caiva prakṛtyā havir ucyate //
column2: The food eaten by hermits in the forest, milk, Soma-juice, meat which is not prepared (with spices), and salt unprepared by art, are called, on account of their nature, sacrificial food.

column1: visṛjya brāhmaṇāṃs tāṃs tu niyato vāgyataḥ śuciḥ / dakṣiṇāṃ diśam ākāṅkṣan yācetemān varān pitṝn //
column2: Having dismissed the (invited) Brahmanas, let him, with a concentrated mind, silent and pure, look towards the south and ask these blessings of the manes:

column1: dātāro no 'bhivardhantāṃ vedāḥ saṃtatir eva ca / śraddhā ca no mā vyagamad bahudeyaṃ ca no 'stv iti //
column2: 'May liberal men abound with us! May (our knowledge of) the Vedas and (our) progeny increase! May faith not forsake us! May we have much to give (to the needy)!'

column1: evaṃ nirvapaṇaṃ kṛtvā piṇḍāṃs tāṃs tadanantaram / gāṃ vipram ajam agniṃ vā prāśayed apsu vā kṣipet //
column2: Having thus offered (the cakes), let him, after (the prayer), cause a cow, a Brahmana, a goat, or the sacred fire to consume those cakes, or let him throw them into water.

column1: piṇḍanirvapaṇaṃ ke cit parastād eva kurvate / vayobhiḥ khādayanty anye prakṣipanty anale 'psu vā //
column2: Some make the offering of the cakes after (the dinner); some cause (them) to be eaten by birds or throw them into fire or into water.

column1: pativratā dharmapatnī pitṛpūjanatatparā / madhyamaṃ tu tataḥ piṇḍam adyāt samyak sutārthinī // āyuṣmantaṃ sutaṃ sūte yaśomedhāsamanvitam / dhanavantaṃ prajāvantaṃ sāttvikaṃ dhārmikaṃ tathā //
column2: The (sacrificer's) first wife, who is faithful and intent on the worship of the manes, may eat the middle-most cake, (if she be) desirous of bearing a son. (Thus) she will bring forth a son who will be long-lived, famous, intelligent, rich, the father of numerous offspring, endowed with (the quality of) goodness, and righteous.

column1: praksālya hastāv ācāmya jñātiprāyaṃ prakalpayet / jñātibhyaḥ satkṛtaṃ dattvā bāndhavān api bhojayet //
column2: Having washed his hands and sipped water, let him prepare (food) for his paternal relations and, after giving it to them with due respect, let him feed his maternal relatives also.

column1: uccheṣaṇaṃ tu tat tiṣṭhed yāvad viprā visarjitāḥ / tato gṛhabaliṃ kuryād iti dharmo vyavasthitaḥ //
column2: But the remnants shall be left (where they lie) until the Brahmanas have been dismissed; afterwards he shall perform the (daily) domestic Bali-offering; that is a settled (rule of the) sacred law.

column1: havir yac cirarātrāya yac cānantyāya kalpate / pitṛbhyo vidhivad dattaṃ tat pravakṣyāmy aśeṣataḥ //
column2: I will now fully declare what kind of sacrificial food, given to the manes according to the rule, will serve for a long time or for eternity.

column1: tilair vrīhiyavair māṣair adbhir mūlaphalena vā / dattena māsaṃ tṛpyanti vidhivat pitaro nṛnām //
column2: The ancestors of men are satisfied for one month with sesamum grains, rice, barley, masha beans, water, roots, and fruits, which have been given according to the prescribed rule,

column1: dvau māsau matsyamāṃsena trīn māsān hāriṇena tu / aurabhreṇātha caturaḥ śākunenātha pañca vai //
column2: Two months with fish, three months with the meat of gazelles, four with mutton, and five indeed with the flesh of birds,

column1: ṣaṇmāsāṃś chāgamāṃsena pārṣatena ca sapta vai / aṣṭāv enasya māṃsena rauraveṇa navaiva tu //
column2: Six months with the flesh of kids, seven with that of spotted deer, eight with that of the black antelope, but nine with that of the (deer called) Ruru,

column1: daśamāsāṃs tu tṛpyanti varāhamahiṣāmiṣaiḥ / śaśakūrmayos tu māṃsena māsān ekādaśaiva tu // saṃvatsaraṃ tu gavyena payasā pāyasena ca / vārdhrīṇasasya māṃsena tṛptir dvādaśavārṣikī //
column2: Ten months they are satisfied with the meat of boars and buffaloes, but eleven months indeed with that of hares and tortoises, One year with cow-milk and milk-rice; from the flesh of a long-eared white he-goat their satisfaction endures twelve years.

column1: kālaśākaṃ mahāśalkāḥ khaṅgalohāmiṣaṃ madhu / ānantyāyaiva kalpyante munyannāni ca sarvaśaḥ //
column2: The (vegetable called) Kalasaka, (the fish called) Mahasalka, the flesh of a rhinoceros and that of a red goat, and all kinds of food eaten by hermits in the forest serve for an endless time.

column1: yat kiṃ cin madhunā miśraṃ pradadyāt tu trayodaśīm / tad apy akṣayam eva syād varṣāsu ca maghāsu ca //
column2: Whatever (food), mixed with honey, one gives on the thirteenth lunar day in the rainy season under the asterism of Maghah, that also procures endless (satisfaction).

column1: api naḥ sa kule bhūyād yo no dadyāt trayodaśīm / pāyasaṃ madhusarpirbhyāṃ prāk chāye kuñjarasya ca //
column2: 'May such a man (the manes say) be born in our family who will give us milk-rice, with honey and clarified butter, on the thirteenth lunar day (of the month of Bhadrapada) and (in the afternoon) when the shadow of an elephant falls towards the east.'

column1: yad yad dadāti vidhivat samyak śraddhāsamanvitaḥ / tat tat pitṝṇāṃ bhavati paratrānantam akṣayam //
column2: Whatever (a man), full of faith, duly gives according to the prescribed rule, that becomes in the other world a perpetual and imperishable (gratification) for the manes.

column1: kṛṣṇapakṣe daśamyādau varjayitvā caturdaśīm / śrāddhe praśastās tithayo yathaitā na tathetarāḥ //
column2: The days of the dark half of the month, beginning with the tenth, but excepting the fourteenth, are recommended for a funeral sacrifice; (it is) not thus (with) the others.

column1: yukṣu kurvan dinarkṣeṣu sarvān kāmān samaśnute / ayukṣu tu pitṝn sarvān prajāṃ prāpnoti puṣkalām //
column2: He who performs it on the even (lunar) days and under the even constellations, gains (the fulfilment of) all his wishes; he who honours the manes on odd (lunar days) and under odd (constellations), obtains distinguished offspring.

column1: yathā caivāparaḥ pakṣaḥ pūrvapakṣād viśiṣyate / tathā śrāddhasya pūrvāhṇād aparāhṇo viśiṣyate //
column2: As the second half of the month is preferable to the first half, even so the afternoon is better for (the performance of) a funeral sacrifice than the forenoon.

column1: prācīnāvītinā samyag apasavyam atandriṇā / pitryam ā nidhanāt kāryaṃ vidhivad darbhapāṇinā //
column2: Let him, untired, duly perform the (rites) in honour of the manes in accordance with the prescribed rule, passing the sacred thread over the right shoulder, proceeding from the left to the right (and) holding Kusa grass in his hands, up to the end (of the ceremony).

column1: rātrau śrāddhaṃ na kurvīta rākṣasī kīrtitā hi sā / saṃdhyayor ubhayoś caiva sūrye caivācirodite //
column2: Let him not perform a funeral sacrifice at night, because the (night) is declared to belong to the Rakshasas, nor in the twilight, nor when the sun has just risen.

column1: anena vidhinā śrāddhaṃ trir abdasyeha nirvapet / hemantagrīṣmavarṣāsu pāñcayajñikam anvaham //
column2: Let him offer here below a funeral sacrifice, according to the rule given above, (at least) thrice a year, in winter, in summer, and in the rainy season, but that which is included among the five great sacrifices, every day.

column1: na paitṛyajñiyo homo laukike 'gnau vidhīyate / na darśena vinā śrāddham āhitāgner dvijanmanaḥ //
column2: The burnt-oblation, offered at a sacrifice to the manes, must not be made in a common fire; a Brahmana who keeps a sacred fire (shall) not (perform) a funeral sacrifice except on the new-moon day.

column1: yad eva tarpayaty adbhiḥ pitṝn snātvā dvijottamaḥ / tenaiva kṛtsnam āpnoti pitṛyajñakriyāphalam //
column2: Even when a Brahmana, after bathing, satisfies the manes with water, he obtains thereby the whole reward for the performance of the (daily) Sraddha.

column1: vasūn vadanti tu pitṝn rudrāṃś caiva pitāmahān / prapitāmahāṃs tathādityān śrutir eṣā sanātanī //
column2: They call (the manes of) fathers Vasus, (those of) grandfathers Rudras, and (those of) great-grandfathers Adityas; thus (speaks) the eternal Veda.

column1: vighasāśī bhaven nityaṃ nityaṃ vāmṛtabhojanaḥ / vighaso bhuktaśeṣaṃ tu yajñaśeṣaṃ tathāmṛtam //
column2: Let him daily partake of the vighasa and daily eat amrita (ambrosia); but vighasa is what remains from the meal (of Brahmana guests) and the remainder of a sacrifice (is called) amrita.

column1: etad vo 'bhihitaṃ sarvaṃ vidhānaṃ pāñcayajñikam / dvijātimukhyavṛttīnāṃ vidhānaṃ śrūyatām iti //
column2: Thus all the ordinances relating to the five (daily great) sacrifices have been declared to you; hear now the law for the manner of living fit for Brahmanas.

column1: caturtham āyuṣo bhāgam uṣitvādyaṃ gurau dvijāḥ / dvitīyam āyuṣo bhāgaṃ kṛtadāro gṛhe vaset //
column2: Having dwelt with a teacher during the fourth part of (a man's) life, a Brahmana shall live during the second quarter (of his existence) in his house, after he has wedded a wife.

column1: adroheṇaiva bhūtānām alpadroheṇa vā punaḥ / yā vṛttis tāṃ samāsthāya vipro jīved anāpadi //
column2: A Brahmana must seek a means of subsistence which either causes no, or at least little pain (to others), and live (by that) except in times of distress.

column1: yātrāmātraprasiddhyarthaṃ svaiḥ karmabhir agarhitaiḥ / akleśena śarīrasya kurvīta dhanasaṃcayam //
column2: For the purpose of gaining bare subsistence, let him accumulate property by (following those) irreproachable occupations (which are prescribed for) his (caste), without (unduly) fatiguing his body.

column1: ṛtāmṛtābhyāṃ jīvet tu mṛtena pramṛtena vā / satyānṛtābhyām api vā na śvavṛttyā kadā cana //
column2: He may subsist by Rita (truth), and Amrita (ambrosia), or by Mrita (death) and by Pramrita (what causes many deaths); or even by (the mode) called Satyanrita (a mixture of truth and falsehood), but never by Svavritti (a dog's mode of life).

column1: ṛtam uñchaśilaṃ jñeyam amṛtaṃ syād ayācitam / mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam //
column2: By Rita shall be understood the gleaning of corn; by Amrita, what is given unasked; by Mrita, food obtained by begging and agriculture is declared to be Pramrita.

column1: satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate / sevā śvavṛttir ākhyātā tasmāt tāṃ parivarjayet //
column2: But trade and (money-lending) are Satyanrita, even by that one may subsist. Service is called Svavritti; therefore one should avoid it.

column1: kusūladhānyako vā syāt kumbhīdhānyaka eva vā / tryahaihiko vāpi bhaved aśvastanika eva vā //
column2: He may either possess enough to fill a granary, or a store filling a grain-jar; or he may collect what suffices for three days, or make no provision for the morrow.

column1: caturṇām api caiteṣāṃ dvijānāṃ gṛhamedhinām / jyāyān paraḥ paro jñeyo dharmato lokajittamaḥ //
column2: Moreover, among these four Brahmana householders, each later-(named) must be considered more distinguished, and through his virtue to have conquered the world more completely.

column1: ṣaṭkarmaiko bhavaty eṣāṃ tribhir anyaḥ pravartate / dvābhyām ekaś caturthas tu brahmasattreṇa jīvati //
column2: One of these follows six occupations, another subsists by three, one by two, but the fourth lives by the Brahmasattra.

column1: vartayaṃś ca śiloñchābhyām agnihotraparāyaṇaḥ / iṣṭīḥ pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ kevalā nirvapet sadā //
column2: He who maintains himself by picking up grains and ears of corn, must be always intent on (the performance of) the Agnihotra, and constantly offer those Ishtis only, which are prescribed for the days of the conjunction and opposition (of the moon), and for the solstices.

column1: na lokavṛttaṃ varteta vṛttihetoḥ kathaṃ cana / ajihmām aśathāṃ śuddhāṃ jīved brāhmaṇajīvikām //
column2: Let him never, for the sake of subsistence, follow the ways of the world; let him live the pure, straightforward, honest life of a Brahmana.

column1: saṃtoṣaṃ param āsthāya sukhārthī saṃyato bhavet / saṃtoṣamūlaṃ hi sukhaṃ duḥkhamūlaṃ viparyayaḥ //
column2: He who desires happiness must strive after a perfectly contented disposition and control himself; for happiness has contentment for its root, the root of unhappiness is the contrary (disposition).

column1: ato 'nyatamayā vṛttyā jīvaṃs tu snātako dvijaḥ / svargāyuṣyayaśasyāni vratāṇīmāni dhārayet //
column2: A Brahmana, who is a Snataka and subsists by one of the (above-mentioned) modes of life, must discharge the (following) duties which secure heavenly bliss, long life, and fame.

column1: vedoditaṃ svakaṃ karma nityaṃ kuryād atandritaḥ / tad dhi kurvan yathāśakti prāpnoti paramāṃ gatim //
column2: Let him, untired, perform daily the rites prescribed for him in the Veda; for he who performs those according to his ability, attains to the highest state.

column1: nehetārthān prasaṅgena na viruddhena karmaṇā / na vidyamāneṣv artheṣu nārtyām api yatas tataḥ //
column2: Whether he be rich or even in distress, let him not seek wealth through pursuits to which men cleave, nor by forbidden occupations, nor (let him accept presents) from any (giver whosoever he may be).

column1: indriyārtheṣu sarveṣu na prasajyeta kāmataḥ / atiprasaktiṃ caiteṣāṃ manasā saṃnivartayet //
column2: Let him not, out of desire (for enjoyments), attach himself to any sensual pleasures, and let him carefully obviate an excessive attachment to them, by (reflecting on their worthlessness in) his heart.

column1: sarvān parityajed arthān svādhyāyasya virodhinaḥ / yathā tathādhyāpayaṃs tu sā hy asya kṛtakṛtyatā //
column2: Let him avoid all (means of acquiring) wealth which impede the study of the Veda; (let him maintain himself) anyhow, but study, because that (devotion to the Veda-study secures) the realisation of his aims.

column1: vayasaḥ karmaṇo 'rthasya śrutasyābhijanasya ca / veṣavāgbuddhisārūpyam ācaran vicared iha //
column2: Let him walk here (on earth), bringing his dress, speech, and thoughts to a conformity with his age, his occupation, his wealth, his sacred learning, and his race.

column1: buddhivṛddhikarāṇy āśu dhanyāni ca hitāni ca / nityaṃ śāstrāṇy avekṣeta nigamāṃś caiva vaidikān //
column2: Let him daily pore over those Institutes of science which soon give increase of wisdom, those which teach the acquisition of wealth, those which are beneficial (for other worldly concerns), and likewise over the Nigamas which explain the Veda.

column1: yathā yathā hi puruṣaḥ śāstraṃ samadhigacchati / tathā tathā vijānāti vijñānaṃ cāsya rocate //
column2: For the more a man completely studies the Institutes of science, the more he fully understands (them), and his great learning shines brightly.

column1: ṛṣiyajñaṃ devayajñaṃ bhūtayajñaṃ ca sarvadā / nṛyajñaṃ pitṛyajñaṃ ca yathāśakti na hāpayet //
column2: Let him never, if he is able (to perform them), neglect the sacrifices to the sages, to the gods, to the Bhutas, to men, and to the manes.

column1: etān eke mahāyajñān yajñaśāstravido janāḥ / anīhamānāḥ satatam indriyeṣv eva juhvati //
column2: Some men who know the ordinances for sacrificial rites, always offer these great sacrifices in their organs (of sensation), without any (external) effort.

column1: vācy eke juhvati prāṇaṃ prāṇe vācaṃ ca sarvadā / vāci prāṇe ca paśyanto yajñanirvṛttim akṣayām //
column2: Knowing that the (performance of the) sacrifice in their speech and their breath yields imperishable (rewards), some always offer their breath in their speech, and their speech in their breath.

column1: jñānenaivāpare viprā yajanty etair makhaiḥ sadā / jñānamūlāṃ kriyām eṣāṃ paśyanto jñānacakṣuṣā //
column2: Other Brahmanas, seeing with the eye of knowledge that the performance of those rites has knowledge for its root, always perform them through knowledge alone.

column1: agnihotraṃ ca juhuyād ādyante dyuniśoḥ sadā / darśena cārdhamāsānte paurṇāmāsena caiva hi //
column2: A Brahmana shall always offer the Agnihotra at the beginning or at the end of the day and of the night, and the Darsa and Paurnamasa (Ishtis) at the end of each half-month,

column1: nāniṣṭvā navasasyeṣṭyā paśunā cāgnimān dvijaḥ / navānnam adyān māṃsaṃ vā dīrgham āyur jijīviṣuḥ //
column2: A Brahmana, who keeps sacred fires, shall, if he desires to live long, not eat new grain or meat, without having offered the (Agrayana) Ishti with new grain and an animal-(sacrifice).

column1: navenānarcitā hy asya paśuhavyena cāgnayaḥ / prāṇān evāttum icchanti navānnāmiṣagardhinaḥ //
column2: For his fires, not being worshipped by offerings of new grain and of an animal, seek to devour his vital spirits, (because they are) greedy for new grain and flesh.

column1: āsanāśanaśayyābhir adbhir mūlaphalena vā / nāsya kaś cid vased gehe śaktito 'narcito 'tithiḥ // pāṣāṇḍino vikarmasthān baiḍālavratikāñ śaṭhān / haitukān bakavṛttīṃś ca vāṅgātreṇāpi nārcayet //
column2: No guest must stay in his house without being honoured, according to his ability, with a seat, food, a couch, water, or roots and fruits. Let him not honour, even by a greeting, heretics, men who follow forbidden occupations, men who live like cats, rogues, logicians, (arguing against the Veda,) and those who live like herons.

column1: vedavidyāvratasnātāñ śrotriyān gṛhamedhinaḥ / pūjayed dhavyakavyena viparītāṃś ca varjayet //
column2: Those who have become Snatakas after studying the Veda, or after completing their vows, (and) householders, who are Srotriyas, one must worship by (gifts of food) sacred to gods and manes, but one must avoid those who are different.

column1: śaktito 'pacamānebhyo dātavyaṃ gṛhamedhinā / saṃvibhāgaś ca bhūtebhyaḥ kartavyo 'nuparodhataḥ //
column2: A householder must give (as much food) as he is able (to spare) to those who do not cook for themselves, and to all beings one must distribute (food) without detriment (to one's own interest).

column1: rājato dhanam anvicchet saṃsīdan snātakaḥ kṣudhā / yājyāntevāsinor vāpi na tv anyata iti sthitiḥ //
column2: A Snataka who pines with hunger, may beg wealth of a king, of one for whom he sacrifices, and of a pupil, but not of others; that is a settled rule.

column1: na sīdet snātako vipraḥ kṣudhā śaktaḥ kathaṃ cana / na jīrṇamalavadvāsā bhavec ca vibhave sati //
column2: A Snataka who is able (to procure food) shall never waste himself with hunger, nor shall he wear old or dirty clothes, if he possesses property.

column1: kḷptakeśanakhaśmaśrur dāntaḥ śuklāmbaraḥ śuciḥ / svādhyāye caiva yuktaḥ syān nityam ātmahiteṣu ca // vaiṇavīṃ dhārayed yaṣṭiṃ sodakaṃ ca kamaṇḍalum / yajñopavītaṃ vedaṃ ca śubhaṃ raukme ca kuṇḍale //
column2: Keeping his hair, nails, and beard clipped, subduing his passions by austerities, wearing white garments and (keeping himself) pure, he shall be always engaged in studying the Veda and (such acts as are) conducive to his welfare. He shall carry a staff of bamboo, a pot full of water, a sacred string, a bundle of Kusa grass, and (wear) two bright golden ear-rings.

column1: nekṣetodyantam ādityaṃ nāstaṃ yāntaṃ kadā cana / nopasṛṣṭaṃ na vāristhaṃ na madhyaṃ nabhaso gatam //
column2: Let him never look at the sun, when he sets or rises, is eclipsed or reflected in water, or stands in the middle of the sky.

column1: na laṅghayed vatsatantrīṃ na pradhāvec ca varṣati / na codake nirīkṣeta svarūpam iti dhāraṇā //
column2: Let him not step over a rope to which a calf is tied, let him not run when it rains, and let him not look at his own image in water; that is a settled rule.

column1: mṛdaṃ gāṃ daivataṃ vipraṃ ghṛtaṃ madhu catuṣpatham / pradakṣiṇāni kurvīta prajñātāṃś ca vanaspatīn //
column2: Let him pass by (a mound of) earth, a cow, an idol, a Brahmana, clarified butter, honey, a crossway, and well-known trees, turning his right hand towards them.

column1: nopagacchet pramatto 'pi striyam ārtavadarśane / samānaśayane caiva na śayīta tayā saha //
column2: Let him, though mad with desire, not approach his wife when her courses appear; nor let him sleep with her in the same bed.

column1: rajasābhiplutāṃ nārīṃ narasya hy upagacchataḥ / prajñā tejo balaṃ cakṣur āyuś caiva prahīyate //
column2: For the wisdom, the energy, the strength, the sight, and the vitality of a man who approaches a woman covered with menstrual excretions, utterly perish.

column1: tāṃ vivarjayatas tasya rajasā samabhiplutām / prajñā tejo balaṃ cakṣur āyuś caiva pravardhate //
column2: If he avoids her, while she is in that condition, his wisdom, energy, strength, sight, and vitality will increase.

column1: nāśnīyād bhāryayā sārdhaṃ nainām īkṣeta cāśnatīm / kṣuvatīṃ jṛmbhamāṇāṃ vā na cāsīnāṃ yathāsukham //
column2: Let him not eat in the company of his wife, nor look at her, while she eats, sneezes, yawns, or sits at her ease.

column1: nāñjayantīṃ svake netre na cābhyaktām anāvṛtām / na paśyet prasavantīṃ ca tejaskāmo dvijottamaḥ //
column2: A Brahmana who desires energy must not look at (a woman) who applies collyrium to her eyes, has anointed or uncovered herself or brings forth (a child).

column1: nānnam adyād ekavāsā na nagnaḥ snānam ācaret / na mūtraṃ pathi kurvīta na bhasmani na govraje //
column2: Let him not eat, dressed with one garment only; let him not bathe naked; let him not void urine on a road, on ashes, or in a cow-pen,

column1: na phālakṛṣṭe na jale na cityāṃ na ca parvate / na jīrṇadevāyatane na valmīke kadā cana //
column2: Nor on ploughed land, in water, on an altar of bricks, on a mountain, on the ruins of a temple, nor ever on an ant-hill,

column1: na sasattveṣu garteṣu na gacchann api na sthitaḥ / na nadītīram āsādya na ca parvatamastake //
column2: Nor in holes inhabited by living creatures, nor while he walks or stands, nor on reaching the bank of a river, nor on the top of a mountain.

column1: vāyvagnivipram ādityam apaḥ paśyaṃs tathaiva gāḥ / na kadā cana kurvīta viṇmūtrasya visarjanam //
column2: Let him never void faeces or urine, facing the wind, or a fire, or looking towards a Brahmana, the sun, water, or cows.

column1: tiraskṛtyoccaret kāṣṭha- loṣṭhapatratṛṇādinā / niyamya prayato vācaṃ saṃvītāṅgo 'vaguṇṭhitaḥ //
column2: He may ease himself, having covered (the ground) with sticks, clods, leaves, grass, and the like, restraining his speech, (keeping himself) pure, wrapping up his body, and covering his head.

column1: mūtroccārasamutsargaṃ divā kuryād udaṅmukhaḥ / dakṣiṇābhimukho rātrau saṃdhyāyoś ca yathā divā //
column2: Let him void faeces and urine, in the daytime turning to the north, at night turning towards the south, during the two twilights in the same (position) as by day.

column1: chāyāyām andhakāre vā rātrāv ahani vā dvijaḥ / yathāsukhamukhaḥ kuryāt prāṇabādhabhayeṣu ca //
column2: In the shade or in darkness a Brahmana may, both by day and at night, do it, assuming any position he pleases; likewise when his life is in danger.

column1: pratyagniṃ pratisūryaṃ ca pratisomodakadvijam / pratigu prativātaṃ ca prajñā naśyati mehataḥ //
column2: The intellect of (a man) who voids urine against a fire, the sun, the moon, in water, against a Brahmana, a cow, or the wind, perishes.

column1: nāgniṃ mukhenopadhamen nagnāṃ nekṣeta ca striyam / nāmedhyaṃ prakṣiped agnau na ca pādau pratāpayet //
column2: Let him not blow a fire with his mouth; let him not look at a naked woman; let him not throw any impure substance into the fire, and let him not warm his feet at it.

column1: adhastān nopadadhyāc ca na cainam abhilaṅghayet / na cainaṃ pādataḥ kuryān na prāṇābādham ācaret // nāśnīyāt saṃdhivelāyāṃ na gacchen nāpi saṃviśet / na caiva pralikhed bhūmiṃ nātmano 'paharet srajam //
column2: Let him not place (fire) under (a bed or the like); nor step over it, nor place it (when he sleeps) at the foot-(end of his bed); let him not torment living creatures. Let him not eat, nor travel, nor sleep during the twilight; let him not scratch the ground; let him not take off his garland.

column1: nāpsu mūtraṃ purīṣaṃ vā ṣṭhīvanaṃ vā samutsṛjet / amedhyaliptam anyad vā lohitaṃ vā viṣāṇi vā //
column2: Let him not throw urine or faeces into the water, nor saliva, nor (clothes) defiled by impure substances, nor any other (impurity), nor blood, nor poisonous things.

column1: naikaḥ supyāc chūnyagehe na śreyāṃsaṃ prabodhayet / nodakyayābhibhāṣeta yajñaṃ gacchen na cāvṛtaḥ //
column2: Let him not sleep alone in a deserted dwelling; let him not wake (a superior) who is sleeping; let him not converse with a menstruating woman; nor let him go to a sacrifice, if he is not chosen (to be officiating priest).

column1: agnyagāre gavāṃ goṣṭhe brāhmaṇānāṃ ca saṃnidhau / svādhyāye bhojane caiva dakṣinaṃ pāṇim uddharet //
column2: Let him keep his right arm uncovered in a place where a sacred fire is kept, in a cow-pen, in the presence of Brahmanas, during the private recitation of the Veda, and at meals.

column1: na vārayed gāṃ dhayantīṃ na cācakṣīta kasya cit / na divīndrāyudhaṃ dṛṣṭvā kasya cid darśayed budhaḥ //
column2: Let him not interrupt a cow who is suckling (her calf), nor tell anybody of it. A wise man, if he sees a rainbow in the sky, must not point it out to anybody.

column1: nādharmike vased grāme na vyādhibahule bhṛśam / naikaḥ prapadyetādhvānaṃ na ciraṃ parvate vaset //
column2: Let him not dwell in a village where the sacred law is not obeyed, nor (stay) long where diseases are endemic; let him not go alone on a journey, nor reside long on a mountain.

column1: na śūdrarājye nivasen nādhārmikajanāvṛte / na pāṣaṇḍigaṇākrānte nopasṣṛṭe 'ntyajair nṛbhiḥ //
column2: Let him not dwell in a country where the rulers are Sudras, nor in one which is surrounded by unrighteous men, nor in one which has become subject to heretics, nor in one swarming with men of the lowest castes.

column1: na bhuñjītoddhṛtasnehaṃ nātisauhityam ācaret / nātiprage nātisāyaṃ na sāyaṃ prātarāśitaḥ // na kurvīta vṛthāceṣṭāṃ na vāry añjalinā pibet / notsaṅge bhakṣayed bhakṣyān na jātu syāt kutūhalī //
column2: Let him not eat anything from which the oil has been extracted; let him not be a glutton; let him not eat very early (in the morning), nor very late (in the evening), nor (take any food) in the evening, if he has eaten (his fill) in the morning. Let him not exert himself without a purpose; let him not drink water out of his joined palms; let him not eat food (placed) in his lap; let him not show (idle) curiosity.

column1: na nṛtyed atha vā gāyen na vāditrāṇi vādayet] / nāsphoṭayen na ca kṣveḍen na ca rakto virāvayet //
column2: Let him not dance, nor sing, nor play musical instruments, nor slap (his limbs), nor grind his teeth, nor let him make uncouth noises, though he be in a passion.

column1: na pādau dhāvayet kāṃsye kadā cid api bhājane / na bhinnabhāṇḍe bhuñjīta na bhāvapratidūṣite //
column2: Let him never wash his feet in a vessel of white brass; let him not eat out of a broken (earthen) dish, nor out of one that (to judge) from its appearance (is) defiled.

column1: upānahau ca vāsaś ca dhṛtam anyair na dhārayet / upavītam alaṅkāraṃ srajaṃ karakam eva ca //
column2: Let him not use shoes, garments, a sacred string, ornaments, a garland, or a water-vessel which have been used by others.

column1: nāvinītair bhajed dhuryair na ca kṣudhvyādhipīḍitaiḥ / na bhinnaśṛṅgākṣikhurair na vāladhivirūpitaiḥ //
column2: Let him not travel with untrained beasts of burden, nor with (animals) that are tormented by hunger or disease, or whose horns, eyes, and hoofs have been injured, or whose tails have been disfigured.

column1: vinītais tu vrajen nityam āśugair lakṣaṇānvitaiḥ / varṇarūpopasaṃpannaiḥ pratodenātudan bhṛśam //
column2: Let him always travel with (beasts) which are well broken in, swift, endowed with lucky marks, and perfect in colour and form, without urging them much with the goad.

column1: bālātapaḥ pretadhūmo varjyaṃ bhinnaṃ tathāsanam / na chindyān nakharomāṇi dantair notpāṭayen nakhān //
column2: The morning sun, the smoke rising from a (burning) corpse, and a broken seat must be avoided. Let him not clip his nails or hair, and not tear his nails with his teeth.

column1: na mṛlloṣṭhaṃ ca mṛdnīyān na chindyāt karajais tṛṇam / na karma niṣphalaṃ kuryān nāyatyām asukhodayam //
column2: Let him not crush earth or clods, nor tear off grass with his nails; let him not do anything that is useless or will have disagreeable results in the future.

column1: loṣṭhamardī tṛṇacchedī nakhakhādī ca yo naraḥ / sa vināśaṃ vrajaty āśu sūcakāśucir eva ca //
column2: A man who crushes clods, tears off grass, or bites his nails, goes soon to perdition, likewise an informer and he who neglects (the rules of) purification.

column1: na vigarhya kathāṃ kuryād bahir mālyaṃ na dhārayet / gavāṃ ca yānaṃ pṛṣṭhena sarvathaiva vigarhitam //
column2: Let him not wrangle; let him not wear a garland over (his hair). To ride on the back of cows (or of oxen) is anyhow a blamable act.

column1: advāreṇa ca nātīyād grāmaṃ vā veśma vāvṛtam / rātrau ca vṛkṣamūlāni dūrataḥ parivarjayet //
column2: Let him not enter a walled village or house except by the gate, and by night let him keep at a long distance from the roots of trees.

column1: nākṣair dīvyet kadā cit tu svayaṃ nopānahau haret / śayanastho na bhuñjīta na pāṇisthaṃ na cāsane // sarvaṃ ca tilasaṃbaddhaṃ nādyād astam ite ravau / na ca nagnaḥ śayīteha na cocchiṣṭaḥ kva cid vrajet //
column2: Let him never play with dice, nor himself take off his shoes; let him not eat, lying on a bed, nor what has been placed in his hand or on a seat. Let him not eat after sunset any (food) containing sesamum grains; let him never sleep naked, nor go anywhere unpurified (after meals).

column1: ārdrapādas tu bhuñjīta nārdrapādas tu saṃviśet / ārdrapādas tu bhuñjāno dīrgham āyur avāpnuyāt //
column2: Let him eat while his feet are (yet) wet (from the ablution), but let him not go to bed with wet feet. He who eats while his feet are (still) wet, will attain long life.

column1: acakṣurviṣayaṃ durgaṃ $ na prapadyeta karhi cit / na viṇmūtram udīkṣeta na bāhubhyāṃ nadīṃ taret //
column2: Let him never enter a place, difficult of access, which is impervious to his eye; let him not look at urine or ordure, nor cross a river (swimming) with his arms.

column1: adhitiṣṭhen na keśāṃs tu na bhasmāsthikapālikāḥ / na kārpāsāsthi na tuṣān dīrgham āyur jijīviṣuḥ //
column2: Let him not step on hair, ashes, bones, potsherds, cotton-seed or chaff, if he desires long life.

column1: na saṃvasec ca patitair na cāṇḍālair na pulkasaiḥ / na mūrkhair nāvaliptaiś ca nāntyair nāntyāvasāyibhiḥ //
column2: Let him not stay together with outcasts, nor with Kandalas, nor with Pukkasas, nor with fools, nor with overbearing men, nor with low-caste men, nor with Antyavasayins.

column1: na śūdrāya matiṃ dadyān nocchiṣṭaṃ na haviṣkṛtam / na cāsyopadiśed dharmaṃ na cāsya vratam ādiśet //
column2: Let him not give to a Sudra advice, nor the remnants (of his meal), nor food offered to the gods; nor let him explain the sacred law (to such a man), nor impose (upon him) a penance.

column1: yo hy asya dharmam ācaṣṭe yaś caivādiśati vratam / so 'saṃvṛtaṃ nāma tamaḥ saha tenaiva majjati //
column2: For he who explains the sacred law (to a Sudra) or dictates to him a penance, will sink together with that (man) into the hell (called) Asamvrita.

column1: na saṃhatābhyāṃ pāṇibhyāṃ kaṇḍūyed ātmanaḥ śiraḥ / na spṛśec caitad ucchiṣṭo na ca snāyād vinā tataḥ // keśagrahān prahārāṃś ca śirasy etān vivarjayet / śiraḥsnātaś ca tailena nāṅgaṃ kiṃ cid api spṛśet //
column2: Let him not scratch his head with both hands joined; let him not touch it while he is impure, nor bathe without (submerging) it. Let him avoid (in anger) to lay hold of (his own or other men's) hair, or to strike (himself or others) on the head. When he has bathed (submerging) his head, he shall not touch any of his limbs with oil.

column1: na rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇīyād arājanyaprasūtitaḥ / sūnācakradhvajavatāṃ veśenaiva ca jīvatām //
column2: Let him not accept presents from a king who is not descended from the Kshatriya race, nor from butchers, oil-manufacturers, and publicans, nor from those who subsist by the gain of prostitutes.

column1: daśasūnāsamaṃ cakraṃ daśacakrasamo dhvajaḥ / daśadhvajasamo veśo daśaveśasamo nṛpaḥ //
column2: One oil-press is as (bad) as ten slaughter-houses, one tavern as (bad as) ten oil-presses, one brothel as (bad as) ten taverns, one king as (bad as) ten brothels.

column1: daśa sūṇāsahasrāṇi yo vāhayati saunikaḥ / tena tulyaḥ smṛto rājā ghoras tasya pratigrahaḥ //
column2: A king is declared to be equal (in wickedness) to a butcher who keeps a hundred thousand slaughter-houses; to accept presents from him is a terrible (crime).

column1: yo rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇāti lubdhasyocchāstravartinaḥ / sa paryāyeṇa yātīmān narakān ekaviṃśatim //
column2: He who accepts presents from an avaricious king who acts contrary to the Institutes (of the sacred law), will go in succession to the following twenty-one hells:

column1: tāmisram andhatāmisraṃ mahārauravarauravau / narakaṃ kālasūtraṃ ca mahānarakam eva ca //
column2: Tamisra, Andhatamisra, Maharaurava, Raurava, the Kalasutra hell, Mahanaraka,

column1: saṃjīvanaṃ mahāvīciṃ tapanaṃ saṃpratāpanam / saṃhātaṃ ca sakākolaṃ kuḍmalaṃ pratimūrtikam //
column2: Samgivana, Mahaviki, Tapana, Sampratapana, Samghata, Sakakola, Kudmala, Putimrittika,

column1: lohaśaṅkum ṛjīṣaṃ ca panthānaṃ śālmalīṃ nadīm / asipatravanaṃ caiva lohadārakam eva ca //
column2: Lohasanku, Rigisha, Pathin, the (flaming) river, Salmala, Asipatravana, and Lohakaraka.

column1: etad vidanto vidvāṃso brāhmaṇā brahmavādinaḥ / na rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇanti pretya śreyo 'bhikāṅkṣiṇaḥ // brāhme muhūrte budhyeta dharmārthau cānucintayet / kāyakleśāṃś ca tanmūlān vedatattvārtham eva ca //
column2: Learned Brahmanas, who know that, who study the Veda and desire bliss after death, do not accept presents from a king. Let him wake in the muhurta, sacred to Brahman, and think of (the acquisition of) spiritual merit and wealth, of the bodily fatigue arising therefrom, and of the true meaning of the Veda.

column1: utthāyāvaśyakaṃ kṛtvā kṛtaśaucaḥ samāhitaḥ / pūrvāṃ saṃdhyāṃ japaṃs tiṣṭhet svakāle cāparāṃ ciram //
column2: When he has risen, has relieved the necessities of nature and carefully purified himself, let him stand during the morning twilight, muttering for a long time (the Gayatri), and at the proper time (he must similarly perform) the evening (devotion).

column1: ṛṣayo dīrghasaṃdhyatvād dīrgham āyur avāpnuyuḥ / prajñāṃ yaśaś ca kīrtiṃ ca brahmavarcasam eva ca //
column2: By prolonging the twilight devotions, the sages obtained long life, wisdom, honour, fame, and excellence in Vedic knowledge.

column1: śrāvaṇyāṃ prauṣṭhapadyāṃ vāpy upākṛtya yathāvidhi / yuktaś chandāṃsy adhīyīta māsān vipro 'rdhapañcamān //
column2: Having performed the Upakarman according to the prescribed rule on (the full moon of the month) Sravana, or on that of Praushthapada (Bhadrapada), a Brahmana shall diligently study the Vedas during four months and a half.

column1: puṣye tu chandasāṃ kuryād bahir utsarjanaṃ dvijaḥ / māghaśuklasya vā prāpte pūrvāhṇe prathame 'hani //
column2: When the Pushya-day (of the month Pausha), or the first day of the bright half of Magha has come, a Brahmana shall perform in the forenoon the Utsargana of the Vedas.

column1: yathāśāstraṃ tu kṛtvaivam utsargaṃ chandasāṃ bahiḥ / viramet pakṣiṇīṃ rātriṃ tad evaikam aharniśam //
column2: Having performed the Utsarga outside (the village), as the Institutes (of the sacred law) prescribe, he shall stop reading during two days and the intervening night, or during that day (of the Utsarga) and (the following) night.

column1: ata ūrdhvaṃ tu chandāṃsi śukleṣu niyataḥ paṭhet / vedāṅgāni ca sarvāṇi kṛṣṇapakṣeṣu saṃpaṭhet //
column2: Afterwards he shall diligently recite the Vedas during the bright (halves of the months), and duly study all the Angas of the Vedas during the dark fortnights.

column1: nāvispaṣṭam adhīyīta na śūdrajanasannidhau / na niśānte pariśrānto brahmādhītya punaḥ svapet //
column2: Let him not recite (the texts) indistinctly, nor in the presence of Sudras; nor let him, if in the latter part of the night he is tired with reciting the Veda, go again to sleep.

column1: yathoditena vidhinā nityaṃ chandaskṛtaṃ paṭhet / brahma chandaskṛtaṃ caiva dvijo yukto hy anāpadi // imān nityam anadhyāyān adhīyāno vivarjayet / adhyāpanaṃ ca kurvāṇaḥ śiṣyāṇāṃ vidhipūrvakam // karṇaśrave 'nile rātrau divā pāṃsusamūhane / etau varṣāsv anadhyāyāv adhyāyajñāḥ pracakṣate //
column2: According to the rule declared above, let him recite the daily (portion of the) Mantras, and a zealous Brahmana, (who is) not in distress, (shall study) the Brahmana and the Mantrasamhita. Let him who studies always avoid (reading) on the following occasions when the Veda-study is forbidden, and (let) him who teaches pupils according to the prescribed rule (do it likewise). Those who know the (rules of) recitation declare that in the rainy season the Veda-study must be stopped on these two (occasions), when the wind is audible at night, and when it whirls up the dust in the day-time.

column1: vidyutstanitavarṣeṣu maholkānāṃ ca saṃplave / ākālikam anadhyāyam eteṣu manur abravīt //
column2: Manu has stated, that when lightning, thunder, and rain (are observed together), or when large fiery meteors fall on all sides, the recitation must be interrupted until the same hour (on the next day, counting from the occurrence of the event).

column1: etāṃs tv abhyuditān vidyād yadā prāduṣkṛtāgniṣu / tadā vidyād anadhyāyam anṛtau cābhradarśane // nirghāte bhūmicalane jyotiṣāṃ copasarjane / etān ākālikān vidyād anadhyāyān ṛtāv api // prāduṣkṛteṣv agniṣu tu vidyutstanitaniḥsvane / sajyotiḥ syād anadhyāyaḥ śeṣe rātrau yathā divā //
column2: When one perceives these (phenomena) all together (in the twilight), after the sacred fires have been made to blaze (for the performance of the Agnihotra), then one must know the recitation of the Veda to be forbidden, and also when clouds appear out of season. On (the occasion of) a preternatural sound from the sky, (of) an earthquake, and when the lights of heaven are surrounded by a halo, let him know that (the Veda-study must be) stopped until the same hour (on the next day), even if (these phenomena happen) in the (rainy) season.

column1: nityānadhyāya eva syād grāmeṣu nagareṣu ca / dharmanaipuṇyakāmānāṃ pūtigandhe ca sarvadā //
column2: For those who wish to acquire exceedingiy great merit, a continual interruption of the Veda-study (is prescribed) in villages and in towns, and (the Veda-study must) always (cease) when any kind of foul smell (is perceptible).

column1: antargataśave grāme vṛṣalasya ca sannidhau / anadhyāyo rudyamāne samavāye janasya ca //
column2: In a village where a corpse lies, in the presence of a (man who lives as unrighteously as a) Sudra, while (the sound of) weeping (is heard), and in a crowd of men the (recitation of the Veda must be) stopped.

column1: udake madhyarātre ca viṇmūtrasya visarjane / ucchiṣṭaḥ śrāddhabhuk caiva manasāpi na cintayet //
column2: In water, during the middle part of the night, while he voids excrements, or is impure, and after he has partaken of a funeral dinner, a man must not even think in his heart (of the sacred texts).

column1: pratigṛhya dvijo vidvān ekoddiṣṭasya ketanam / tryahaṃ na kīrtayed brahma rājño rāhoś ca sūtake //
column2: A learned Brahmana shall not recite the Veda during three days, when he has accepted an invitation to a (funeral rite) in honour of one ancestor (ekoddishta), or when the king has become impure through a birth or death in his family (sutaka), or when Rahu by an eclipse makes the moon impure.

column1: yāvad ekānudiṣṭasya gandho lepaś ca tiṣṭhati / viprasya viduṣo dehe tāvad brahma na kīrtayet //
column2: As long as the smell and the stains of the (food given) in honour of one ancestor remain on the body of a learned Brahmana, so long he must not recite the Veda.

column1: śayānaḥ prauḍhapādaś ca kṛtvā caivāvasakthikām / nādhīyītāmiṣaṃ jagdhvā sūtakānnādyam eva ca // nīhāre bāṇaśabde ca saṃdhyayor eva cobhayoḥ / amāvāsyācaturdaśyoḥ paurṇamāsyaṣṭakāsu ca //
column2: While lying on a bed, while his feet are raised (on a bench), while he sits on his hams with a cloth tied round his knees, let him not study, nor when he has eaten meat or food given by a person impure on account of a birth or a death, Nor during a fog, nor while the sound of arrows is audible, nor during both the twilights, nor on the new-moon day, nor on the fourteenth and the eighth (days of each half-month), nor on the full-moon day.

column1: amāvāsyā guruṃ hanti śiṣyaṃ hanti caturdaśī / brahmāṣṭakapaurṇamāsyau tasmāt tāḥ parivarjayet //
column2: The new-moon day destroys the teacher, the fourteenth (day) the pupil, the eighth and the full-moon days (destroy all remembrance of) the Veda; let him therefore avoid (reading on) those (days).

column1: pāṃsuvarṣe diśāṃ dāhe gomāyuvirute tathā / śvakharoṣṭre ca ruvati paṅktau ca na paṭhed dvijaḥ // nādhīyīta śmaśānānte grāmānte govraje 'pi vā / vasitvā maithunaṃ vāsaḥ śrāddhikaṃ pratigṛhya ca //
column2: A Brahmana shall not recite (the Veda) during a dust-storm, nor while the sky is preternaturally red, nor while jackals howl, nor while the barking of dogs, the braying of donkeys, or the grunting of camels (is heard), nor while (he is seated) in a company. Let him not study near a burial-ground, nor near a village, nor in a cow-pen, nor dressed in a garment which he wore during conjugal intercourse, nor after receiving a present at a funeral sacrifice.

column1: prāṇi vā yadi vāprāṇi yat kiṃ cic chrāddhikaṃ bhavet / tad ālabhyāpy anadhyāyaḥ pāṇyāsyo hi dvijaḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: Be it an animal or a thing inanimate, whatever be the (gift) at a Sraddha, let him not, having just accepted it, recite the Veda; for the hand of a Brahmana is his mouth.

column1: corair upadrute grāme saṃbhrame cāgnikārite / ākālikam anadhyāyaṃ vidyāt sarvādbhuteṣu ca //
column2: When the village has been beset by robbers, and when an alarm has been raised by fire, let him know that (the Veda-study must be) interrupted until the same hour (on the next day), and on (the occurrence of) all portents.

column1: upākarmaṇi cotsarge trirātraṃ kṣepaṇaṃ smṛtam / aṣṭakāsu tv ahorātram ṛtvantāsu ca rātriṣu //
column2: On (the occasion of) the Upakarman and (of) the Vedotsarga an omission (of the Veda-study) for three days has been prescribed, but on the Ashtakas and on the last nights of the seasons for a day and a night.

column1: nādhīyītāśvam ārūḍho na vṛkṣaṃ na ca hastinam / na nāvaṃ na kharaṃ noṣṭraṃ neriṇastho na yānagaḥ //
column2: Let him not recite the Veda on horseback, nor on a tree, nor on an elephant, nor in a boat (or ship), nor on a donkey, nor on camel, nor standing on barren ground, nor riding in a carriage,

column1: na vivāde na kalahe na senāyāṃ na saṃgare / na bhuktamātre nājīrṇe na vamitvā na śuktake //
column2: Nor during a verbal altercation, nor during a mutual assault, nor in a camp, nor during a battle, nor when he has just eaten, nor during an indigestion, nor after vomiting, nor with sour eructations,

column1: atithiṃ cānanujñāpya mārute vāti vā bhṛśam / rudhire ca srute gātrāc chastreṇa ca parikṣate // sāmadhvanāv ṛgyajuṣī nādhīyīta kadā cana / vedasyādhītya vāpy antam āraṇyakam adhītya ca //
column2: Nor without receiving permission from a guest (who stays in his house), nor while the wind blows vehemently, nor while blood flows from his body, nor when he is wounded by a weapon. Let him never recite the Rig-veda or the Yagur-veda while the Saman (melodies) are heard; (let him stop all Veda-study for a day and a night) after finishing a Veda or after reciting an Aranyaka.

column1: ṛgvedo devadaivatyo yajurvedas tu mānuṣaḥ / sāmavedaḥ smṛtaḥ pitryas tasmāt tasyāśucir dhvaniḥ //
column2: The Rig-veda is declared to be sacred to the gods, the Yagur-veda sacred to men, and the Sama-veda sacred to the manes; hence the sound of the latter is impure (as it were).

column1: etad vidvanto vidvāṃsas trayīniṣkarṣam anvaham / kramataḥ pūrvam abhyasya paścād vedam adhīyate //
column2: Knowing this, the learned daily repeat first in due order the essence of the three (Vedas) and afterwards the (text of the) Veda.

column1: paśumaṇḍūkamārjāra- śvasarpanakulākhubhiḥ / antarāgamane vidyād anadhyāyam aharniśam //
column2: Know that (the Veda-study must be) interrupted for a day and a night, when cattle, a frog, a cat, a dog, a snake, an ichneumon, or a rat pass between (the teacher and his pupil).

column1: dvāv eva varjayen nityam anadhyāyau prayatnataḥ / svādhyāyabhūmiṃ cāśuddham ātmānaṃ cāśuciṃ dvijaḥ //
column2: Let a twice-born man always carefully interrupt the Veda-study on two (occasions, viz.) when the place where he recites is impure, and when he himself is unpurified.

column1: amāvāsyām aṣṭamīṃ ca paurṇamāsīṃ caturdaśīm / brahmacārī bhaven nityam apy ṛtau snātako dvijaḥ //
column2: A twice-born man who is a Snataka shall remain chaste on the new-moon day, on the eighth (lunar day of each half-month), on the full-moon day, and on the fourteenth, even (if they fall) in the period (proper for conjugal intercourse).

column1: na snānam ācared bhuktvā nāturo na mahāniśi / na vāsobhiḥ sahājasraṃ nāvijñāte jalāśaye //
column2: Let him not bathe (immediately) after a meal, nor when he is sick, nor in the middle of the night, nor frequently dressed in all his garments, nor in a pool which he does not perfectly know.

column1: devatānāṃ guro rājñaḥ snātakācāryayos tathā / nākrāmet kāmataś chāyāṃ babhruṇo dīkṣitasya ca //
column2: Let him not intentionally step on the shadow of (images of) the gods, of a Guru, of a king, of a Snataka, of his teacher, of a reddish-brown animal, or of one who has been initiated to the performance of a Srauta sacrifice (Dikshita).

column1: madhyaṃdine 'rdharātre ca śrāddhaṃ bhuktvā ca sāmiṣam / saṃdhyayor ubhayoś caiva na seveta catuṣpatham //
column2: At midday and at midnight, after partaking of meat at a funeral dinner, and in the two twilights let him not stay long on a cross-road.

column1: udvartanam apasnānaṃ viṇmūtre raktam eva ca / śleśmaniṣṭhyūtavāntāni nādhitiṣṭhet tu kāmataḥ //
column2: Let him not step intentionally on things used for cleansing the body, on water used for a bath, on urine or ordure, on blood, on mucus, and on anything spat out or vomited.

column1: vairiṇaṃ nopaseveta sahāyaṃ caiva vairiṇaḥ / adhārmikaṃ taskaraṃ ca parasyaiva ca yoṣitaṃ //
column2: Let him not show particular attention to an enemy, to the friend of an enemy, to a wicked man, to a thief, or to the wife of another man.

column1: na hīdṛśam anāyuṣyaṃ loke kiṃ cana vidyate / yādṛśaṃ puruṣasyeha paradāropasevanam //
column2: For in this world there is nothing so detrimental to long life as criminal conversation with another man's wife.

column1: kṣatriyaṃ caiva sarpaṃ ca brāhmaṇaṃ ca bahuśrutam / nāvamanyeta vai bhūṣṇuḥ kṛśān api kadā cana //
column2: Let him who desires prosperity, indeed, never despise a Kshatriya, a snake, and a learned Brahmana, be they ever so feeble.

column1: etat trayaṃ hi puruṣaṃ nirdahed avamānitam / tasmād etat trayaṃ nityaṃ nāvamanyeta buddhimān //
column2: Because these three, when treated with disrespect, may utterly destroy him; hence a wise man must never despise them.

column1: nātmānam avamanyeta purvābhir asamṛddhibhiḥ / ā mṛtyoḥ śriyam anvicchen naināṃ manyeta durlabhām //
column2: Let him not despise himself on account of former failures; until death let him seek fortune, nor despair of gaining it.

column1: satyaṃ brūyāt priyaṃ brūyān na brūyāt satyam apriyam / priyaṃ ca nānṛtaṃ brūyād eṣa dharmaḥ sanātanaḥ //
column2: Let him say what is true, let him say what is pleasing, let him utter no disagreeable truth, and let him utter no agreeable falsehood; that is the eternal law.

column1: bhadraṃ bhadram iti brūyād bhadram ity eva vā vadet / śuṣkavairaṃ vivādaṃ ca na kuryāt kena cit saha //
column2: (What is) well, let him call well, or let him say 'well' only; let him not engage in a useless enmity or dispute with anybody.

column1: nātikalyaṃ nātisāyaṃ nātimadhyaṃdine sthite / nājñātena samaṃ gacchen naiko na vṛṣalaiḥ saha //
column2: Let him not journey too early in the morning, nor too late in the evening, nor just during the midday (heat), nor with an unknown (companion), nor alone, nor with Sudras.

column1: hīnāṅgān atiriktāṅgān vidyāhīnān vayo'dhikān / rūpadraviṇahīnāṃś ca jātihīnāṃś ca nākṣipet //
column2: Let him not insult those who have redundant limbs or are deficient in limbs, nor those destitute of knowledge, nor very aged men, nor those who have no beauty or wealth, nor those who are of low birth.

column1: na spṛśet pāṇinocchiṣṭo vipro gobrāhmaṇānalāṇ / na cāpi paśyed aśuciḥ sustho jyotirgaṇān divā //
column2: A Brahmana who is impure must not touch with his hand a cow, a Brahmana, or fire; nor, being in good health, let him look at the luminaries in the sky, while he is impure.

column1: spṛṣṭvaitān aśucir nityam adbhiḥ prāṇān upaspṛśet / gātrāṇi caiva sarvāṇi nābhiṃ pāṇitalena tu //
column2: If he has touched these, while impure, let him always sprinkle with his hand water on the organs of sensation, all his limbs, and the navel.

column1: anāturaḥ svāni khāni na spṛśed animittataḥ / romāṇi ca rahasyāni sarvāṇy eva vivarjayet // maṅgalācārayuktaḥ syāt prayatātmā jitendriyaḥ / japec ca juhuyāc caiva nityam agnim atandritaḥ //
column2: Except when sick he must not touch the cavities (of the body) without a reason, and he must avoid (to touch) the hair on the secret (parts). Let him eagerly follow the (customs which are) auspicious and the rule of good conduct, be careful of purity, and control all his organs, let him mutter (prayers) and, untired, daily offer oblations in the fire.

column1: maṅgalācārayuktānāṃ nityaṃ ca prayatātmanām / japatāṃ juhvatāṃ caiva vinipāto na vidyate //
column2: No calamity happens to those who eagerly follow auspicious customs and the rule of good conduct, to those who are always careful of purity, and to those who mutter (sacred texts) and offer burnt-oblations.

column1: vedam evābhyasen nityaṃ yathākālam atandritaḥ / taṃ hy asyāhuḥ paraṃ dharmam upadharmo 'nya ucyate //
column2: Let him, without tiring, daily mutter the Veda at the proper time; for they declare that to be one's highest duty; (all) other (observances) are called secondary duties.

column1: vedābhyāsena satataṃ śaucena tapasaiva ca / adroheṇa ca bhūtānāṃ jātiṃ smarati paurvikīm //
column2: By daily reciting the Veda, by (the observance of the rules of) purification, by (practising) austerities, and by doing no injury to created beings, one (obtains the faculty of) remembering former births.

column1: paurvikīṃ saṃsmaran jātiṃ brahmaivābhyasyate punaḥ / brahmābhyāsena cājasram anantaṃ sukham aśnute //
column2: He who, recollecting his former existences, again recites the Veda, gains endless bliss by the continual study of the Veda.

column1: sāvitrāñ śāntihomāṃś ca kuryāt parvasu nityaśaḥ / pitṝṃś caivāṣṭakāsv arcen nityam anvaṣṭakāsu ca //
column2: Let him always offer on the Parva-days oblations to Savitri and such as avert evil omens, and on the Ashtakas and Anvashtakas let him constantly worship the manes.

column1: dūrād āvasathān mūtraṃ dūrāt pādāvasecanam / ucchiṣṭānnaniṣekaṃ ca dūrād eva samācaret //
column2: Far from his dwelling let him remove urine (and ordure), far (let him remove) the water used for washing his feet, and far the remnants of food and the water from his bath.

column1: maitraṃ prasādhanaṃ snānaṃ dantadhāvanam añjanam / pūrvāhṇa eva kurvīta devatānāṃ ca pūjanam //
column2: Early in the morning only let him void faeces, decorate (his body), bathe, clean his teeth, apply collyrium to his eyes, and worship the gods.

column1: daivatāny abhigacchet tu dhārmikāṃś ca dvijottamān / īśvaraṃ caiva rakṣārthaṃ gurūn eva ca parvasu //
column2: But on the Parva-days let him go to visit the (images of the) gods, and virtuous Brahmanas, and the ruler (of the country), for the sake of protection, as well as his Gurus.
