column1: abhivādayed vṛddhāṃś ca dadyāc caivāsanaṃ svakam / kṛtāñjalir upāsīta gacchataḥ pṛṣṭhato 'nviyāt //
column2: Let him reverentially salute venerable men (who visit him), give them his own seat, let him sit near them with joined hands and, when they leave, (accompany them), walking behind them.

column1: śrutismṛtyuditaṃ samyaṅ nibaddhaṃ sveṣu karmasu / dharmamūlaṃ niṣeveta sadācāram atandritaḥ //
column2: Let him, untired, follow the conduct of virtuous men, connected with his occupations, which has been fully declared in the revealed texts and in the sacred tradition (Smriti) and is the root of the sacred law.

column1: ācārāl labhate hy āyur ācārād īpsitāḥ prajāḥ / ācārād dhanam akṣayyam ācāro hanty alakṣaṇam //
column2: Through virtuous conduct he obtains long life, through virtuous conduct desirable offspring, through virtuous conduct imperishable wealth; virtuous conduct destroys (the effect of) inauspicious marks.

column1: durācāro hi puruṣo loke bhavati ninditaḥ / duḥkhabhāgī ca satataṃ vyādhito 'lpāyur eva ca //
column2: For a man of bad conduct is blamed among people, constantly suffers misfortunes, is afflicted with diseases, and short-lived.

column1: sarvalakṣaṇahīno 'pi yaḥ sadācāravān naraḥ / śraddadhāno 'nasūyaś ca śataṃ varṣāṇi jīvati //
column2: A man who follows the conduct of the virtuous, has faith and is free from envy, lives a hundred years, though he be entirely destitute of auspicious marks.

column1: yad yat paravaśaṃ karma tat tad yatnena varjayet / yad yad ātmavaśaṃ tu syāt tat tat seveta yatnataḥ //
column2: Let him carefully avoid all undertakings (the success of) which depends on others; but let him eagerly pursue that (the accomplishment of) which depends on himself.

column1: sarvaṃ paravaśaṃ duḥkhaṃ sarvam ātmavaśaṃ sukham / etad vidyāt samāsena lakṣaṇaṃ sukhaduḥkhayoḥ //
column2: Everything that depends on others (gives) pain, everything that depends on oneself (gives) pleasure; know that this is the short definition of pleasure and pain.

column1: yat karma kurvato 'sya syāt paritoṣo 'ntarātmanaḥ / tat prayatnena kurvīta viparītaṃ tu varjayet //
column2: When the performance of an act gladdens his heart, let him perform it with diligence; but let him avoid the opposite.

column1: ācāryaṃ ca pravaktāraṃ pitaraṃ mātaraṃ gurum / na hiṃsyād brāhmaṇān gāś ca sarvāṃś caiva tapasvinaḥ //
column2: Let him never offend the teacher who initiated him, nor him who explained the Veda, nor his father and mother, nor (any other) Guru, nor cows, nor Brahmanas, nor any men performing austerities.

column1: nāstikyaṃ vedanindāṃ ca devatānāṃ ca kutsanam / dveṣaṃ dambhaṃ ca mānaṃ ca krodhaṃ taikṣṇyaṃ ca varjayet //
column2: Let him avoid atheism, cavilling at the Vedas, contempt of the gods, hatred, want of modesty, pride, anger, and harshness.

column1: parasya daṇḍaṃ nodyacchet kruddho nainaṃ nipātayet / anyatra putrāc chiṣyād vā śiṣṭyarthaṃ tāḍayet tu tau //
column2: Let him, when angry, not raise a stick against another man, nor strike (anybody) except a son or a pupil; those two he may beat in order to correct them.

column1: brāhmaṇāyāvaguryaiva dvijātir vadhakāmyayā / śataṃ varṣāṇi tāmisre narake parivartate //
column2: A twice-born man who has merely threatened a Brahmana with the intention of (doing him) a corporal injury, will wander about for a hundred years in the Tamisra hell.

column1: tāḍayitvā tṛṇenāpi saṃrambhān matipūrvakam / ekaviṃśatīm ājātīḥ pāpayoniṣu jāyate //
column2: Having intentionally struck him in anger, even with a blade of grass, he will be born during twenty-one existences in the wombs (of such beings where men are born in punishment of their) sins.

column1: ayudhyamānasyotpādya brāhmaṇasyāsṛg aṅgataḥ / duḥkhaṃ sumahad āpnoti pretyāprājñatayā naraḥ //
column2: A man who in his folly caused blood to flow from the body of a Brahmana who does not attack him, will suffer after death exceedingly great pain.

column1: śoṇitaṃ yāvataḥ pāṃsūn saṃgṛhṇāti mahītalāt / tāvato 'bdān amutrānyaiḥ śoṇitotpādako 'dyate //
column2: As many particles of dust as the blood takes up from the ground, during so many years the spiller of the blood will be devoured by other (animals) in the next world.

column1: na kadā cid dvije tasmād vidvān avagured api / na tāḍayet tṛṇenāpi na gātrāt srāvayed asṛk //
column2: A wise man should therefore never threaten a Brahmana, nor strike him even with a blade of grass, nor cause his blood to flow.

column1: adhārmiko naro yo hi yasya cāpy anṛtaṃ dhanam / hiṃsārataś ca yo nityaṃ nehāsau sukham edhate //
column2: Neither a man who (lives) unrighteously, nor he who (acquires) wealth (by telling) falsehoods, nor he who always delights in doing injury, ever attain happiness in this world.

column1: na sīdann api dharmeṇa mano 'dharme niveśayet / adhārmikānāṃ pāpānām āśu paśyan viparyayam //
column2: Let him, though suffering in consequence of his righteousness, never turn his heart to unrighteousness; for he will see the speedy overthrow of unrighteous, wicked men.

column1: nādharmaś carito loke sadyaḥ phalati gaur iva / śanair āvartyamānas tu kartur mūlāni kṛntati //
column2: Unrighteousness, practised in this world, does not at once produce its fruit, like a cow; but, advancing slowly, it cuts off the roots of him who committed it.

column1: yadi nātmani putreṣu na cet putreṣu naptṛṣu / na tv eva tu kṛto 'dharmaḥ kartur bhavati niṣphalaḥ //
column2: If (the punishment falls) not on (the offender) himself, (it falls) on his sons, if not on the sons, (at least) on his grandsons; but an iniquity (once) committed, never fails to produce fruit to him who wrought it.

column1: adharmeṇaidhate tāvat tato bhadrāṇi paśyati / tataḥ sapatnān jayati samūlas tu vinaśyati //
column2: He prospers for a while through unrighteousness, then he gains great good fortune, next he conquers his enemies, but (at last) he perishes (branch and) root.

column1: satyadharmāryavṛtteṣu śauce caivāramet sadā / śiṣyāṃś ca śiṣyād dharmeṇa vāgbāhūdarasaṃyataḥ //
column2: Let him always delight in truthfulness, (obedience to) the sacred law, conduct worthy of an Aryan, and purity; let him chastise his pupils according to the sacred law; let him keep his speech, his arms, and his belly under control.

column1: parityajed arthakāmau yau syātāṃ dharmavarjitau / dharmaṃ cāpy asukhodarkaṃ lokasaṃkruṣṭam eva ca //
column2: Let him avoid (the acquisition of) wealth and (the gratification of his) desires, if they are opposed to the sacred law, and even lawful acts which may cause pain in the future or are offensive to men.

column1: na pāṇipādacapalo na netracapalo 'nṛjuḥ / na syād vākcapalaś caiva na paradrohakarmadhīḥ //
column2: Let him not be uselessly active with his hands and feet, or with his eyes, nor crooked (in his ways), nor talk idly, nor injure others by deeds or even think of it.

column1: yenāsya pitaro yātā yena yātāḥ pitāmahāḥ / tena yāyāt satāṃ mārgaṃ tena gacchan na riṣyati //
column2: Let him walk in that path of holy men which his fathers and his grandfathers followed; while he walks in that, he will not suffer harm.

column1: ṛtvikpurohitācāryair mātulātithisaṃśritaiḥ / bālavṛddhāturair vaidyair jñātisaṃbandhibāndhavaiḥ //
column2: With an officiating or a domestic priest, with a teacher, with a maternal uncle, a guest and a dependant, with infants, aged and sick men, with learned men, with his paternal relatives, connexions by marriage and maternal relatives,

column1: mātāpitṛbhyāṃ jāmībhir bhrātrā putreṇa bhāryayā / duhitrā dāsavargeṇa vivādaṃ na samācaret //
column2: With his father and his mother, with female relatives, with a brother, with his son and his wife, with his daughter and with his slaves, let him not have quarrels.

column1: etair vivādān saṃtyajya sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate / etair jitaiś ca jayati sarvāṃl lokān imān gṛhī //
column2: If he avoids quarrels with these persons, he will be freed from all sins, and by suppressing (all) such (quarrels) a householder conquers all the following worlds.

column1: ācāryo brahmalokeśaḥ prājāpatye pitā prabhuḥ / atithis tv indralokeśo devalokasya ca rtvijaḥ //
column2: The teacher is the lord of the world of Brahman, the father has power over the world of the Lord of created beings (Pragapati), a guest rules over the world of Indra, and the priests over the world of the gods.

column1: jāmayo 'psarasāṃ loke vaiśvadevasya bāndhavāḥ / saṃbandhino hy apāṃ loke pṛthivyāṃ mātṛmātulau //
column2: The female relatives (have power) over the world of the Apsarases, the maternal relatives over that of the Visve Devas, the connexions by marriage over that of the waters, the mother and the maternal uncle over the earth.

column1: ākāśeśās tu vijñeyā bālavṛddhakṛśāturāḥ / bhrātā jyeṣṭhaḥ samaḥ pitrā bhāryā putraḥ svakā tanuḥ // chāyā svo dāsavargaś ca duhitā kṛpaṇaṃ param / tasmād etair adhikṣiptaḥ sahetāsaṃjvaraḥ sadā //
column2: Infants, aged, poor and sick men must be considered as rulers of the middle sphere, the eldest brother as equal to one's father, one's wife and one's son as one's own body, One's slaves as one's shadow, one's daughter as the highest object of tenderness; hence if one is offended by (any one of) these, one must bear it without resentment.

column1: pratigrahasamartho 'pi prasaṅgaṃ tatra varjayet / pratigraheṇa hy asyāśu brāhmaṃ tejaḥ praśāmyati //
column2: Though (by his learning and sanctity) he may be entitled to accept presents, let him not attach himself (too much) to that (habit); for through his accepting (many) presents the divine light in him is soon extinguished.

column1: na dravyāṇām avijñāya vidhiṃ dharmyaṃ pratigrahe / prājñaḥ pratigrahaṃ kuryād avasīdann api kṣudhā //
column2: Without a full knowledge of the rules, prescribed by the sacred law for the acceptance of presents, a wise man should not take anything, even though he may pine with hunger.

column1: hiraṇyaṃ bhūmim aśvaṃ gām annaṃ vāsas tilān ghṛtam / pratigṛhṇann avidvāṃs tu bhasmībhavati dāruvat //
column2: But an ignorant (man) who accepts gold, land, a horse, a cow, food, a dress, sesamum-grains, (or) clarified butter, is reduced to ashes like (a piece of) wood.

column1: hiraṇyam āyur annaṃ ca bhūr gauś cāpy oṣatas tanum / aśvaś cakṣus tvacaṃ vāso ghṛtaṃ tejas tilāh prajāḥ //
column2: Gold and food destroy his longevity, land and a cow his body, a horse his eye (sight), a garment his skin, clarified butter his energy, sesamum-grains his offspring.

column1: atapās tv anadhīyānaḥ pratigraharucir dvijaḥ / ambhasy aśmaplaveneva saha tenaiva majjati //
column2: A Brahmana who neither performs austerities nor studies the Veda, yet delights in accepting gifts, sinks with the (donor into hell), just as (he who attempts to cross over in) a boat made of stone (is submerged) in the water.

column1: tasmād avidvān bibhiyād yasmāt tasmāt pratigrahāt / svalpakenāpy avidvān hi paṅke gaur iva sīdati //
column2: Hence an ignorant (man) should be afraid of accepting any presents; for by reason of a very small (gift) even a fool sinks (into hell) as a cow into a morass.

column1: na vāry api prayacchet tu baiḍālavratike dvije / na bakavratike pāpe nāvedavidi dharmavit //
column2: (A man) who knows the law should not offer even water to a Brahmana who acts like a cat, nor to a Brahmana who acts like a heron, nor to one who is unacquainted with the Veda.

column1: triṣv apy eteṣu dattaṃ hi vidhināpy arjitaṃ dhanam / dātur bhavaty anarthāya paratrādātur eva ca //
column2: For property, though earned in accordance with prescribed rules, which is given to these three (persons), causes in the next world misery both to the giver and to the recipient.

column1: yathā plavenāupalena nimajjaty udake taran / tathā nimajjato 'dhastād ajñau dātṛpratīcchakau //
column2: As he who (attempts to) cross water in a boat of stone sinks (to the bottom), even so an ignorant donor and an ignorant donee sink low.

column1: dharmadhvajī sadā lubdhaś chādmiko lokadambhakaḥ / baiḍālavratiko jñeyo hiṃsraḥ sarvābhisaṃdhakaḥ //
column2: (A man) who, ever covetous, displays the flag of virtue, (who is) a hypocrite, a deceiver of the people, intent on doing injury, (and) a detractor (from the merits) of all men, one must know to be one who acts like a cat.

column1: adhodṛṣṭir naiṣkṛtikaḥ svārthasādhanatatparaḥ / śaṭho mithyāvinītaś ca bakavratacaro dvijaḥ //
column2: That Brahmana, who with downcast look, of a cruel disposition, is solely intent on attaining his own ends, dishonest and falsely gentle, is one who acts like a heron.

column1: ye bakavratino viprā ye ca mārjāraliṅginaḥ / te patanty andhatāmisre tena pāpena karmaṇā //
column2: Those Brahmanas who act like herons, and those who display the characteristics of cats, fall in consequence of that wicked mode of acting into (the hell called) Andhatamisra.

column1: na dharmasyāpadeśena pāpaṃ kṛtvā vrataṃ caret / vratena pāpaṃ pracchādya kurvan strīśūdradambhanam //
column2: When he has committed a sin, let him not perform a penance under the pretence (that the act is intended to gain) spiritual merit, (thus) hiding his sin under (the pretext of) a vow and deceiving women and Sudras.

column1: pretyeha cedṛśā viprā garhyante brahmavādibhiḥ / chadmanā caritaṃ yac ca vrataṃ rakṣāṃsi gacchati //
column2: Such Brahmanas are reprehended after death and in this (life) by those who expound the Veda, and a vow, performed under a false pretence, goes to the Rakshasas.

column1: aliṅgī liṅgiveṣeṇa yo vṛttim upajīvati / sa liṅgināṃ haraty enas tiryagyonau ca jāyate //
column2: He who, without being a student, gains his livelihood by (wearing) the dress of a student, takes upon himself the guilt of (all) students and is born again in the womb of an animal.

column1: parakīyanipāneṣu na snāyād dhi kadā cana / nipānakartuḥ snātvā tu duṣkṛtāṃśena lipyate //
column2: Let him never bathe in tanks belonging to other men; if he bathes (in such a one), he is tainted by a portion of the guilt of him who made the tank.

column1: yānaśayyāsanāny asya kūpodyānagṛhāṇi ca / adattāny upayuñjāna enasaḥ syāt turīyabhāk //
column2: He who uses without permission a carriage, a bed, a seat, a well, a garden or a house belonging to an (other man), takes upon himself one fourth of (the owner's) guilt.

column1: nadīṣu devakhāteṣu taḍāgeṣu saraḥsu ca / snānaṃ samācaren nityaṃ gartaprasravaṇeṣu ca //
column2: Let him always bathe in rivers, in ponds, dug by the gods (themselves), in lakes, and in waterholes or springs.

column1: yamān seveta satataṃ na nityaṃ niyamān budhaḥ / yamān pataty akurvāṇo niyamān kevalān bhajan //
column2: A wise man should constantly discharge the paramount duties (called yama), but not always the minor ones (called niyama); for he who does not discharge the former, while he obeys the latter alone, becomes an outcast.

column1: nāśrotriyatate yajñe grāmayājikṛte tathā / striyā klībena ca hute bhuñjīta brāhmaṇaḥ kva cit //
column2: A Brahmana must never eat (a dinner given) at a sacrifice that is offered by one who is not a Srotriya, by one who sacrifices for a multitude of men, by a woman, or by a eunuch.

column1: aślīkam etat sādhūnāṃ yatra juhvaty amī haviḥ / pratīpam etad devānāṃ tasmāt tat parivarjayet //
column2: When those persons offer sacrificial viands in the fire, it is unlucky for holy (men) it displeases the gods; let him therefore avoid it.

column1: mattakruddhāturāṇāṃ ca na bhuñjīta kadā cana / keśakīṭāvapannaṃ ca padā spṛṣṭaṃ ca kāmataḥ // bhrūṇaghnāvekṣitaṃ caiva saṃspṛṣṭaṃ cāpy udakyayā / patatriṇāvalīḍhaṃ ca śunā saṃspṛṣṭam eva ca //
column2: Let him never eat (food given) by intoxicated, angry, or sick (men), nor that in which hair or insects are found, nor what has been touched intentionally with the foot, Nor that at which the slayer of a learned Brahmana has looked, nor that which has been touched by a menstruating woman, nor that which has been pecked at by birds or touched by a dog,

column1: gavā cānnam upaghrātaṃ ghuṣṭānnaṃ ca viśeṣataḥ / gaṇānnaṃ gaṇikānnaṃ ca viduṣā ca jugupsitam //
column2: Nor food at which a cow has smelt, nor particularly that which has been offered by an invitation to all comers, nor that (given) by a multitude or by harlots, nor that which is declared to be had by a learned (man),

column1: stenagāyanayoś cānnaṃ takṣṇo vārdhuṣikasya ca / dīkṣitasya kadaryasya baddhasya nigaḍasya ca //
column2: Nor the food (given) by a thief, a musician, a carpenter, a usurer, one who has been initiated (for the performance of a Srauta sacrifice), a miser, one bound with fetters,

column1: abhiśastasya ṣaṇḍhasya puṃścalyā dāmbhikasya ca / śuktaṃ paryuṣitaṃ caiva śūdrasyocchiṣṭam eva ca // cikitsakasya mṛgayoḥ krūrasyocchiṣṭabhojinaḥ / ugrānnaṃ sūtikānnaṃ ca paryācāntam anirdaśam // anarcitaṃ vṛthāmāṃsam avīrāyāś ca yoṣitaḥ / dviṣadannaṃ nagaryannaṃ patitānnam avakṣutam //
column2: Nor (the food given) by a physician, a hunter, a cruel man, one who eats the fragments (of another's meal), nor the food of an Ugra, nor that prepared for a woman in childbed, nor that (given at a dinner) where (a guest rises) prematurely (and) sips water, nor that (given by a woman) whose ten days of impurity have not elapsed, Nor (food) given without due respect, nor (that which contains) meat eaten for no sacred purpose, nor (that given) by a female who has no male (relatives), nor the food of an enemy, nor that (given) by the lord of a town, nor that (given) by outcasts, nor that on which anybody has sneezed;

column1: piśunānṛtinoś cānnaṃ kratuvikrayiṇas tathā / śailūṣatunnavāyānnaṃ kṛtaghnasyānnam eva ca // karmārasya niṣādasya raṅgāvatārakasya ca / suvarṇakartur veṇasya śastravikrayiṇas tathā //
column2: Nor the food (given) by an informer, by one who habitually tells falsehoods, or by one who sells (the rewards for) sacrifices, nor the food (given) by an actor, a tailor, or an ungrateful (man), By a blacksmith, a Nishada, a stage-player, a goldsmith, a basket-maker, or a dealer in weapons,

column1: śvavatāṃ śauṇḍikānāṃ ca cailanirṇejakasya ca / rañjakasya nṛśaṃsasya yasya copapatir gṛhe //
column2: By trainers of hunting dogs, publicans, a washerman, a dyer, a pitiless (man), and a man in whose house (lives) a paramour (of his wife),

column1: mṛṣyanti ye copapatiṃ strījitānāṃ ca sarvaśaḥ / anirdaśaṃ ca pretānnam atuṣṭikaram eva ca //
column2: Nor (the food given) by those who knowingly bear with paramours (of their wives), and by those who in all matters are ruled by women, nor food (given by men) whose ten days of impurity on account of a death have not passed, nor that which is unpalatable.

column1: rājānnaṃ teja ādatte śūdrānnaṃ brahmavarcasam / āyuḥ suvarṇakārānnaṃ yaśaś carmāvakartinaḥ //
column2: The food of a king impairs his vigour, the food of a Sudra his excellence in sacred learning, the food of a goldsmith his longevity, that of a leather-cutter his fame;

column1: kārukānnaṃ prajāṃ hanti balaṃ nirṇejakasya ca / gaṇānnaṃ gaṇikānnaṃ ca lokebhyaḥ parikṛntati //
column2: The food of an artisan destroys his offspring, that of a washerman his (bodily) strength; the food of a multitude and of harlots excludes him from (the higher) worlds.

column1: pūyaṃ cikitsakasyānnaṃ puṃścalyās tv annam indriyam / viṣṭhā vārdhuṣikasyānnaṃ śastravikrayiṇo malam //
column2: The food of a physician (is as vile as) pus, that of an unchaste woman (equal to) semen, that of a usurer (as vile as) ordure, and that of a dealer in weapons (as bad as) dirt.

column1: ya ete 'nye tv abhojyānnāḥ kramaśaḥ parikīrtitāḥ / teṣāṃ tvagasthiromāṇi vadanty annaṃ manīṣiṇaḥ //
column2: The food of those other persons who have been successively enumerated as such whose food must not be eaten, the wise declare (to be as impure as) skin, bones, and hair.

column1: bhuktvāto 'nyatam asyānnam amatyā kṣapaṇaṃ tryaham / matyā bhuktvācaret kṛcchraṃ retoviṇmūtram eva ca //
column2: If he has unwittingly eaten the food of one of those, (he must) fast for three days; if he has eaten it intentionally, or (has swallowed) semen, ordure, or urine, he must perform a Krikkhra penance.

column1: nādyāc chūdrasya pakvānnaṃ vidvān aśrāddhino dvijaḥ / ādadītāmam evāsmād avṛttāv ekarātrikam //
column2: A Brahmana who knows (the law) must not eat cooked food (given) by a Sudra who performs no Sraddhas; but, on failure of (other) means of subsistence, he may accept raw (grain), sufficient for one night (and day).

column1: śrotriyasya kadaryasya vadānyasya ca vārdhuṣeḥ / mīmāṃsitvobhayaṃ devāḥ samam annam akalpayan //
column2: The gods, having considered (the respective merits) of a niggardly Srotriya and of a liberal usurer, declared the food of both to be equal (in quality).

column1: tān prajāpatir āhaitya mā kṛdhvaṃ viṣamaṃ samam / śraddhāpūtaṃ vadānyasya hatam aśraddhayetarat //
column2: The Lord of created beings (Pragapati) came and spake to them, 'Do not make that equal, which is unequal. The food of that liberal (usurer) is purified by faith; (that of the) of the) other (man) is defiled by a want of faith.'

column1: śraddhayeṣṭaṃ ca pūrtaṃ ca nityaṃ kuryād atandritaḥ / śraddhākṛte hy akṣaye te bhavataḥ svāgatair dhanaiḥ // dānadharmaṃ niṣeveta nityam aiṣṭikapaurtikam / parituṣṭena bhāvena pātram āsādya śaktitaḥ //
column2: Let him, without tiring, always offer sacrifices and perform works of charity with faith; for offerings and charitable works made with faith and with lawfully-earned money, (procure) endless rewards. Let him always practise, according to his ability, with a cheerful heart, the duty of liberality, both by sacrifices and by charitable works, if he finds a worthy recipient (for his gifts.)

column1: yat kiṃ cid api dātavyaṃ yācitenānasūyayā / utpatsyate hi tat pātraṃ yat tārayati sarvataḥ //
column2: If he is asked, let him always give something, be it ever so little, without grudging; for a worthy recipient will (perhaps) be found who saves him from all (guilt).

column1: vāridas tṛptim āpnoti sukham akṣayyam annadaḥ / tilapradaḥ prajām iṣṭāṃ dīpadaś cakṣur uttamam //
column2: A giver of water obtains the satisfaction (of his hunger and thirst), a giver of food imperishable happiness, a giver of sesamum desirable offspring, a giver of a lamp a most excellent eyesight.

column1: bhūmido bhūmim āpnoti dīrgham āyur hiraṇyadaḥ / gṛhado 'gryāṇi veśmāni rūpyado rūpam uttamam //
column2: A giver of land obtains land, a giver of gold long life, a giver of a house most excellent mansions, a giver of silver (rupya) exquisite beauty (rupa),

column1: vāsodaś candrasālokyam aśvisālokyam aśvadaḥ / anaḍuhaḥ śriyaṃ puṣṭāṃ godo bradhnasya viṣṭapam // yānaśayyāprado bhāryām aiśvaryam abhayapradaḥ / dhānyadaḥ śāśvataṃ saukhyaṃ brahmado brahmasārṣṭitām // sarveṣām eva dānānāṃ brahmadānaṃ viśiṣyate / vāryannagomahīvāsas- tilakāñcanasarpiṣām //
column2: A giver of a garment a place in the world of the moon, a giver of a horse (asva) a place in the world of the Asvins, a giver of a draught-ox great good fortune, a giver of a cow the world of the sun; A giver of a carriage or of a bed a wife, a giver of protection supreme dominion, a giver of grain eternal bliss, a giver of the Veda (brahman) union with Brahman; The gift of the Veda surpasses all other gifts, water, food, cows, land, clothes, sesamum, gold, and clarified butter.

column1: yena yena tu bhāvena yad yad dānaṃ prayacchati / tat tat tenaiva bhāvena prāpnoti pratipūjitaḥ //
column2: For whatever purpose (a man) bestows any gift, for that same purpose he receives (in his next birth) with due honour its (reward).

column1: yo 'rcitaṃ pratigṛhṇāti dadāty arcitam eva vā / tāv ubhau gacchataḥ svargaṃ narakaṃ tu viparyaye //
column2: Both he who respectfully receives (a gift), and he who respectfully bestows it, go to heaven; in the contrary case (they both fall) into hell.

column1: na vismayeta tapasā vaded iṣṭvā ca nānṛtam / nārto 'py apavaded viprān na dattvā parikīrtayet //
column2: Let him not be proud of his austerities; let him not utter a falsehood after he has offered a sacrifice; let him not speak ill of Brahmanas, though he be tormented (by them); when he has bestowed (a gift), let him not boast of it.

column1: yajño 'nṛtena kṣarati tapaḥ kṣarati vismayāt / āyur viprāpavādena dānaṃ ca parikīrtanāt //
column2: By falsehood a sacrifice becomes vain, by self-complacency (the reward for) austerities is lost, longevity by speaking evil of Brahmanas, and (the reward of) a gift by boasting.

column1: dharmaṃ śanaiḥ saṃcinuyād valmīkam iva puttikāḥ / paralokasahāyārthaṃ sarvabhūtāny apīḍayan //
column2: Giving no pain to any creature, let him slowly accumulate spiritual merit, for the sake (of acquiring) a companion to the next world, just as the white ant (gradually raises its) hill.

column1: nāmutra hi sahāyārthaṃ pitā mātā ca tiṣṭhataḥ / na putradāraṃ na jñātir dharmas tiṣṭhati kevalaḥ //
column2: For in the next world neither father, nor mother, nor wife, nor sons, nor relations stay to be his companions; spiritual merit alone remains (with him).

column1: ekaḥ prajāyate jantur eka eva pralīyate / eko 'nubhuṅkte sukṛtam eka eva ca duṣkṛtam //
column2: Single is each being born; single it dies; single it enjoys (the reward of its) virtue; single (it suffers the punishment of its) sin.

column1: mṛtaṃ śarīram utsṛjya kāṣṭhaloṣṭasamaṃ kṣitau / vimukhā bāndhavā yānti dharmas tam anugacchati //
column2: Leaving the dead body on the ground like a log of wood, or a clod of earth, the relatives depart with averted faces; but spiritual merit follows the (soul).

column1: tasmād dharmaṃ sahāyārthaṃ nityaṃ saṃcinuyāc chanaiḥ / dharmeṇa hi sahāyena tamas tarati dustaram //
column2: Let him therefore always slowly accumulate spiritual merit, in order (that it may be his) companion (after death); for with merit as his companion he will traverse a gloom difficult to traverse.

column1: dharmapradhānaṃ puruṣaṃ tapasā hatakilbiṣam / paralokaṃ nayaty āśu bhāsvantaṃ khaśarīriṇam //
column2: (That companion) speedily conducts the man who is devoted to duty and effaces his sins by austerities, to the next world, radiant and clothed with an ethereal body.

column1: uttamair uttamair nityaṃ saṃbandhān ācaret saha / ninīṣuḥ kulam utkarṣam adhamān adhamāṃs tyajet //
column2: Let him, who desires to raise his race, ever form connexions with the most excellent (men), and shun all low ones.

column1: uttamān uttamān eva gacchan hīnāṃs tu varjayan / brāhmaṇaḥ śreṣṭhatām eti pratyavāyena śūdratām //
column2: A Brahmana who always connects himself with the most excellent (ones), and shuns all inferior ones, (himself) becomes most distinguished; by an opposite conduct he becomes a Sudra.

column1: dṛḍhakārī mṛdur dāntaḥ krūrācārair asaṃvasan / ahiṃsro damadānābhyāṃ jayet svargaṃ tathāvrataḥ //
column2: He who is persevering, gentle, (and) patient, shuns the company of men of cruel conduct, and does no injury (to living creatures), gains, if he constantly lives in that manner, by controlling his organs and by liberality, heavenly bliss.

column1: edhodakaṃ mūlaphalam annam abhyudyataṃ ca yat / sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyān madhv athābhayadakṣiṇām //
column2: He may accept from any (man), fuel, water, roots, fruit, food offered without asking, and honey, likewise a gift (which consists in) a promise of protection.

column1: āhṛtābhyudyatāṃ bhikṣāṃ purastād apracoditām / mene prajāpatir grāhyām api duṣkṛtakarmaṇaḥ //
column2: The Lord of created beings (Pragapati) has declared that alms freely offered and brought (by the giver himself) may be accepted even from a sinful man, provided (the gift) had not been (asked for or) promised beforehand.

column1: nāśnanti pitaras tasya daśavarṣāṇi pañca ca / na ca havyaṃ vahaty agnir yas tām abhyavamanyate //
column2: During fifteen years the manes do not eat (the food) of that man who disdains a (freely-offered gift), nor does the fire carry his offerings (to the gods).

column1: śayyāṃ gṛhān kuśān gandhān apaḥ puṣpaṃ maṇīn dadhi / dhānā matsyān payo māṃsaṃ śākaṃ caiva na nirṇudet //
column2: A couch, a house, Kusa grass, perfumes, water, flowers, jewels, sour milk, grain, fish, sweet milk, meat, and vegetables let him not reject, (if they are voluntarily offered.)

column1: gurūn bhṛtyāṃś cojjihīrṣann arciṣyan devatātithīn / sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyān na tu tṛpyet svayaṃ tataḥ // guruṣu tv abhyatīteṣu vinā vā tair gṛhe vasan / ātmano vṛttim anvicchan gṛhṇīyāt sādhutaḥ sadā //
column2: He who desires to relieve his Gurus and those whom he is bound to maintain, or wishes to honour the gods and guests, may accept (gifts) from anybody; but he must not satisfy his (own hunger) with such (presents). But if his Gurus are dead, or if he lives separate from them in (another) house, let him, when he seeks a subsistence, accept (presents) from good men alone.

column1: ārdhikaḥ kulamitraṃ ca gopālo dāsanāpitau / ete śūdreṣu bhojyānnā yāś cātmānaṃ nivedayet //
column2: His labourer in tillage, a friend of his family, his cow-herd, his slave, and his barber are, among Sudras, those whose food he may eat, likewise (a poor man) who offers himself (to be his slave).

column1: yādṛśo 'sya bhaved ātmā yādṛśaṃ ca cikīrṣitam / yathā copacared enaṃ tathātmānaṃ nivedayet //
column2: As his character is, as the work is which he desires to perform, and as the manner is in which he means to serve, even so (a voluntary slave) must offer himself.

column1: yo 'nyathā santam ātmānam anyathā satsu bhāṣate / sa pāpakṛttamo loke stena ātmāpahārakaḥ //
column2: He who describes himself to virtuous (men), in a manner contrary to truth, is the most sinful (wretch) in this world; he is a thief who makes away with his own self.

column1: vācy arthā niyatāḥ sarve vāṅgūlā vāgviniḥsṛtāḥ / tāṃs tu yaḥ stenayed vācaṃ sa sarvasteyakṛn naraḥ //
column2: All things (have their nature) determined by speech; speech is their root, and from speech they proceed; but he who is dishonest with respect to speech, is dishonest in everything.

column1: maharṣipitṛdevānāṃ gatvānṛṇyaṃ yathāvidhi / putre sarvaṃ samāsajya vasen mādhyasthyam āśritaḥ //
column2: When he has paid, according to the law, his debts to the great sages, to the manes, and to the gods, let him make over everything to his son and dwell (in his house), not caring for any worldly concerns.

column1: ekākī cintayen nityaṃ vivikte hitam ātmanaḥ / ekākī cintayāno hi paraṃ śreyo 'dhigacchati //
column2: Alone let him constantly meditate in solitude on that which is salutary for his soul; for he who meditates in solitude attains supreme bliss.

column1: eṣoditā gṛhasthasya vṛttir viprasya śāśvatī / snātakavratakalpaś ca sattvavṛddhikaraḥ śubhaḥ //
column2: Thus have been declared the means by which a Brahmana householder must always subsist, and the summary of the ordinances for a Snataka, which cause an increase of holiness and are praiseworthy.

column1: anena vipro vṛttena vartayan vedaśāstravit / vyapetakalmaṣo nityaṃ brahmaloke mahīyate //
column2: A Brahmana who, being learned in the lore of the Vedas, conducts himself in this manner and daily destroys his sins, will be exalted in Brahman's world.

column1: śrutvaitān ṛṣayo dharmān snātakasya yathoditān / idam ūcur mahātmānam analaprabhavaṃ bhṛgum //
column2: The sages, having heard the duties of a Snataka thus declared, spoke to great-souled Bhrigu, who sprang from fire:

column1: evaṃ yathoktaṃ viprāṇāṃ svadharmam anutiṣṭhatām / kathaṃ mṛtyuḥ prabhavati vedaśāstravidāṃ prabho //
column2: 'How can Death have power over Brahmanas who know the sacred science, the Veda, (and) who fulfil their duties as they have been explained (by thee), O Lord? '

column1: sa tān uvāca dharmātmā maharṣīn mānavo bhṛguḥ / śrūyatāṃ yena doṣeṇa mṛtyur viprān jighāṃsati //
column2: Righteous Bhrigu, the son of Manu, (thus) answered the great sages: 'Hear, (in punishment) of what faults Death seeks to shorten the lives of Brahmanas!'

column1: anabhyāsena vedānām ācārasya ca varjanāt / ālasyād annadoṣāc ca mṛtyur viprāñ jighāṃsati //
column2: 'Through neglect of the Veda-study, through deviation from the rule of conduct, through remissness (in the fulfilment of duties), and through faults (committed by eating forbidden) food, Death becomes eager to shorten the lives of Brahmanas.'

column1: laśunaṃ gṛñjanaṃ caiva palāṇḍuṃ kavakāni ca / abhakṣyāṇi dvijātīnām amedhyaprabhavāni ca //
column2: Garlic, leeks and onions, mushrooms and (all plants), springing from impure (substances), are unfit to be eaten by twice-born men.

column1: lohitān vṛkṣaniryāsān vṛścanaprabhavāṃs tathā / śeluṃ gavyaṃ ca peyūṣaṃ prayatnena vivarjayet //
column2: One should carefully avoid red exudations from trees and (juices) flowing from incisions, the Selu (fruit), and the thickened milk of a cow (which she gives after calving).

column1: vṛthā kṛsarasaṃyāvaṃ pāyasāpūpam eva ca / anupākṛtamāṃsāni devānnāni havīṃṣi ca // anirdaśāyā goḥ kṣīram auṣṭram aikaśaphaṃ tathā / āvikaṃ saṃdhinīkṣīraṃ vivatsāyāś ca goḥ payaḥ //
column2: Rice boiled with sesamum, wheat mixed with butter, milk and sugar, milk-rice and flour-cakes which are not prepared for a sacrifice, meat which has not been sprinkled with water while sacred texts were recited, food offered to the gods and sacrificial viands, The milk of a cow (or other female animal) within ten days after her calving, that of camels, of one-hoofed animals, of sheep, of a cow in heat, or of one that has no calf with her,

column1: āraṇyānāṃ ca sarveṣāṃ mṛgāṇāṃ māhiṣaṃ vinā / strīkṣīraṃ caiva varjyāni sarvaśuktāni caiva hi //
column2: (The milk) of all wild animals excepting buffalo-cows, that of women, and all (substances turned) sour must be avoided.

column1: dadhi bhakṣyaṃ ca śukteṣu sarvaṃ ca dadhisaṃbhavam / yāni caivābhiṣūyante puṣpamūlaphalaiḥ śubhaiḥ //
column2: Among (things turned) sour, sour milk, and all (food) prepared of it may be eaten, likewise what is extracted from pure flowers, roots, and fruit.

column1: kravyādāñ śakunān sarvāṃs tathā grāmanivāsinaḥ / anirdiṣṭāṃś caikaśaphāṃṣ ṭiṭṭibhaṃ ca vivarjayet //
column2: Let him avoid all carnivorous birds and those living in villages, and one-hoofed animals which are not specially permitted (to be eaten), and the Tittibha (Parra Jacana),

column1: kalaviṅkaṃ plavaṃ haṃsaṃ cakrāhvaṃ grāmakukkuṭam / sārasaṃ rajjuvālaṃ ca dātyūhaṃ śukasārike //
column2: The sparrow, the Plava, the Hamsa, the Brahmani duck, the village-cock, the Sarasa crane, the Raggudala, the woodpecker, the parrot, and the starling,

column1: pratudāñ jālapādāṃś ca koyaṣṭinakhaviṣkirān / nimajjataś ca matsyādān saunaṃ vallūram eva ca //
column2: Those which feed striking with their beaks, web-footed birds, the Koyashti, those which scratch with their toes, those which dive and live on fish, meat from a slaughter-house and dried meat,

column1: bakaṃ caiva balākāṃ ca kākolaṃ khañjarīṭakam / matsyādān viḍvarāhāṃś ca matsyān eva ca sarvaśaḥ //
column2: The Baka and the Balaka crane, the raven, the Khangaritaka, (animals) that eat fish, village-pigs, and all kinds of fishes.

column1: yo yasya māṃsam aśnāti sa tanmāṃsāda ucyate / matsyādaḥ sarvamāṃsādas tasmān matsyān vivarjayet //
column2: He who eats the flesh of any (animal) is called the eater of the flesh of that (particular creature), he who eats fish is an eater of every (kind of) flesh; let him therefore avoid fish.

column1: pāṭhīnarohitāv ādyau niyuktau havyakavyayoḥ / rājīvān siṃhatuṇḍāś ca saśalkāś caiva sarvaśaḥ //
column2: (But the fish called) Pathina and (that called) Rohita may be eaten, if used for offerings to the gods or to the manes; (one may eat) likewise Ragivas, Simhatundas, and Sasalkas on all (occasions).

column1: na bhakṣayed ekacarān ajñātāṃś ca mṛgadvijān / bhakṣyeṣv api samuddiṣṭān sarvān pañcanakhāṃs tathā // śvāvidhaṃ śalyakaṃ godhāṃ khaḍgakūrmaśaśāṃs tathā / bhakṣyān pañcanakheṣv āhur anuṣṭrāṃś caikatodatah //
column2: Let him not eat solitary or unknown beasts and birds, though they may fall under (the categories of) eatable (creatures), nor any five-toed (animals). The porcupine, the hedgehog, the iguana, the rhinoceros, the tortoise, and the hare they declare to be eatable; likewise those (domestic animals) that have teeth in one jaw only, excepting camels.

column1: chatrākaṃ viḍvarāhaṃ ca laśunaṃ grāmakukkuṭam / palāṇḍuṃ gṛñjanaṃ caiva matyā jagdhvā pated dvijaḥ //
column2: A twice-born man who knowingly eats mushrooms, a village-pig, garlic, a village-cock, onions, or leeks, will become an outcast.

column1: amatyaitāni ṣaḍ jagdhvā kṛcchraṃ sāntapanaṃ caret / yaticāndrāyāṇaṃ vāpi śeṣeṣūpavased ahaḥ //
column2: He who unwittingly partakes of (any of) these six, shall perform a Samtapana (Krikkhra) or the lunar penance (Kandrayana) of ascetics; in case (he who has eaten) any other (kind of forbidden food) he shall fast for one day (and a night ).

column1: saṃvatsarasyaikam api caret kṛcchraṃ dvijottamaḥ / ajñātabhuktaśuddhyarthaṃ jñātasya tu viṣeśataḥ //
column2: Once a year a Brahmana must perform a Krikkhra penance, in order to atone for unintentionally eating (forbidden food) but for intentionally (eating forbidden food he must perform the penances prescribed) specially.

column1: yajñārthaṃ brāhmaṇair vadhyāḥ praśastā mṛgapakṣiṇaḥ / bhṛtyānāṃ caiva vṛttyartham agastyo hy ācarat purā // babhūvur hi puroḍāśā bhakṣyāṇāṃ mṛgapakṣiṇām / purāṇeṣv api yajñeṣu brahmakṣatrasaveṣu ca //
column2: Beasts and birds recommended (for consumption) may be slain by Brahmanas for sacrifices, and in order to feed those whom they are bound to maintain; for Agastya did this of old. For in ancient (times) the sacrificial cakes were (made of the flesh) of eatable beasts and birds at the sacrifices offered by Brahmanas and Kshatriyas.

column1: yat kiṃ cit snehasaṃyuktaṃ bhakṣyaṃ bhojyam agarhitam / tat paryuṣitam apy ādyaṃ haviḥśeṣaṃ ca yad bhavet //
column2: All lawful hard or soft food may be eaten, though stale, (after having been) mixed with fatty (substances), and so may the remains of sacrificial viands.

column1: cirasthitam api tv ādyam asnehāktaṃ dvijātibhiḥ / yavagodhūmajaṃ sarvaṃ payasaś caiva vikriyā //
column2: But all preparations of barley and wheat, as well as preparations of milk, may be eaten by twice-born men without being mixed with fatty (substances), though they may have stood for a long time.

column1: etad uktaṃ dvijātīnāṃ bhakṣyābhakṣyam aśeṣataḥ / māṃsasyātaḥ pravakṣyāmi vidhiṃ bhakṣaṇavarjane // prokṣitaṃ bhakṣayen māṃsaṃ brāhmaṇānāṃ ca kāmyayā / yathāvidhi niyuktas tu prāṇānām eva cātyaye //
column2: Thus has the food, allowed and forbidden to twice-born men, been fully described; I will now propound the rules for eating and avoiding meat. One may eat meat when it has been sprinkled with water, while Mantras were recited, when Brahmanas desire (one's doing it), when one is engaged (in the performance of a rite) according to the law, and when one's life is in danger.

column1: prāṇasyānnam idaṃ sarvaṃ prajāpatir akalpayat / sthāvaraṃ jaṅgamaṃ caiva sarvaṃ prāṇasya bhojanam //
column2: The Lord of creatures (Pragapati) created this whole (world to be) the sustenance of the vital spirit; both the immovable and the movable (creation is) the food of the vital spirit.

column1: carāṇām annam acarā daṃṣṭriṇām apy adaṃṣṭriṇaḥ / ahastāś ca sahastānāṃ śūrāṇāṃ caiva bhīravaḥ //
column2: What is destitute of motion is the food of those endowed with locomotion; (animals) without fangs (are the food) of those with fangs, those without hands of those who possess hands, and the timid of the bold.

column1: nāttā duṣyaty adann ādyān prāṇino 'hanyahany api / dhātraiva sṛṣṭā hy ādyāś ca prāṇino 'ttāra eva ca //
column2: The eater who daily even devours those destined to be his food, commits no sin; for the creator himself created both the eaters and those who are to be eaten (for those special purposes).

column1: yajñāya jagdhir māṃsasyety eṣa daivo vidhiḥ smṛtaḥ / ato 'nyathā pravṛttis tu rākṣaso vidhir ucyate //
column2: 'The consumption of meat (is befitting) for sacrifices,' that is declared to be a rule made by the gods; but to persist (in using it) on other (occasions) is said to be a proceeding worthy of Rakshasas.

column1: krītvā svayaṃ vāpy utpādya paropakṛtam eva vā / devān pitṝṃś cārcayitvā khādan māṃsaṃ na duṣyati //
column2: He who eats meat, when he honours the gods and manes, commits no sin, whether he has bought it, or himself has killed (the animal), or has received it as a present from others.

column1: nādyād avidhinā māṃsaṃ vidhijño 'nāpadi dvijaḥ / jagdhvā hy avidhinā māṃsaṃ pretas tair adyate 'vaśaḥ //
column2: A twice-born man who knows the law, must not eat meat except in conformity with the law; for if he has eaten it unlawfully, he will, unable to save himself, be eaten after death by his (victims).

column1: na tādṛśaṃ bhavaty eno mṛgahantur dhanārthinaḥ / yādṛśaṃ bhavati pretya vṛthāmāṃsāni khādataḥ //
column2: After death the guilt of one who slays deer for gain is not as (great) as that of him who eats meat for no (sacred) purpose.

column1: niyuktas tu yathānyāyaṃ yo māṃsaṃ nātti mānavaḥ / sa pretya paśutāṃ yāti saṃbhavān ekaviṃśatim //
column2: But a man who, being duly engaged (to officiate or to dine at a sacred rite), refuses to eat meat, becomes after death an animal during twenty-one existences.

column1: asaṃskṛtān paśūn mantrair nādyād vipraḥ kadā cana / mantrais tu saṃskṛtān adyāc chāśvataṃ vidhim āsthitaḥ //
column2: A Brahmana must never eat (the flesh of animals unhallowed by Mantras; but, obedient to the primeval law, he may eat it, consecrated with Vedic texts.

column1: kuryād ghṛtapaśuṃ saṅge kuryāt piṣṭapaśuṃ tathā / na tv eva tu vṛthā hantuṃ paśum icchet kadā cana //
column2: If he has a strong desire (for meat) he may make an animal of clarified butter or one of flour, (and eat that); but let him never seek to destroy an animal without a (lawful) reason.

column1: yāvanti paśuromāṇi tāvatkṛtvo ha māraṇam / vṛthāpaśughnaḥ prāpnoti pretya janmani janmani //
column2: As many hairs as the slain beast has, so often indeed will he who killed it without a (lawful) reason suffer a violent death in future births.

column1: yajñārthaṃ paśavaḥ sṛṣṭāḥ svayam eva svayaṃbhuvā / yajño 'sya bhūtyai sarvasya tasmād yajñe vadho 'vadhaḥ //
column2: Svayambhu (the Self-existent) himself created animals for the sake of sacrifices; sacrifices (have been instituted) for the good of this whole (world); hence the slaughtering (of beasts) for sacrifices is not slaughtering (in the ordinary sense of the word).

column1: oṣadhyaḥ paśavo vṛkṣās tiryañcaḥ pakṣiṇas tathā / yajñārthaṃ nidhanaṃ prāptāḥ prāpnuvanty utsṛtīḥ punaḥ //
column2: Herbs, trees, cattle, birds, and (other) animals that have been destroyed for sacrifices, receive (being reborn) higher existences.

column1: madhuparke ca yajñe ca pitṛdaivatakarmaṇi / atraiva paśavo hiṃsyā nānyatrety abravīn manuḥ //
column2: On offering the honey-mixture (to a guest), at a sacrifice and at the rites in honour of the manes, but on these occasions only, may an animal be slain; that (rule) Manu proclaimed.

column1: eṣv artheṣu paśūn hiṃsan vedatattvārthavid dvijaḥ / ātmānaṃ ca paśuṃ caiva gamayaty uttamaṃ gatim //
column2: A twice-born man who, knowing the true meaning of the Veda, slays an animal for these purposes, causes both himself and the animal to enter a most blessed state.

column1: gṛhe gurāv araṇye vā nivasann ātmavān dvijaḥ / nāvedavihitāṃ hiṃsām āpady api samācaret //
column2: A twice-born man of virtuous disposition, whether he dwells in (his own) house, with a teacher, or in the forest, must never, even in times of distress, cause an injury (to any creature) which is not sanctioned by the Veda.

column1: yā vedavihitā hiṃsā niyatāsmiṃś carācare / ahiṃsām eva tāṃ vidyād vedād dharmo hi nirbabhau //
column2: Know that the injury to moving creatures and to those destitute of motion, which the Veda has prescribed for certain occasions, is no injury at all; for the sacred law shone forth from the Veda.

column1: yo 'hiṃsakāni bhūtāni hinasty ātmasukhecchayā / sa jīvāṃś ca mṛtaś caiva na kva cit sukham edhate //
column2: He who injures innoxious beings from a wish to (give) himself pleasure, never finds happiness, neither living nor dead.

column1: yo bandhanavadhakleśān prāṇināṃ na cikīrṣati / sa sarvasya hitaprepsuḥ sukham atyantam aśnute //
column2: He who does not seek to cause the sufferings of bonds and death to living creatures, (but) desires the good of all (beings), obtains endless bliss.

column1: yad dhyāyati yat kurute ratiṃ badhnāti yatra ca / tad avāpnoty ayatnena yo hinasti na kiṃ cana //
column2: He who does not injure any (creature), attains without an effort what he thinks of, what he undertakes, and what he fixes his mind on.

column1: nākṛtvā prāṇināṃ hiṃsāṃ māṃsam utpadyate kva cit / na ca prāṇivadhaḥ svargyas tasmān māṃsaṃ vivarjayet //
column2: Meat can never be obtained without injury to living creatures, and injury to sentient beings is detrimental to (the attainment of) heavenly bliss; let him therefore shun (the use of) meat.

column1: samutpattiṃ ca māṃsasya vadhabandhau ca dehinām / prasamīkṣya nivarteta sarvamāṃsasya bhakṣaṇāt //
column2: Having well considered the (disgusting) origin of flesh and the (cruelty of) fettering and slaying corporeal beings, let him entirely abstain from eating flesh.

column1: na bhakṣayati yo māṃsaṃ vidhiṃ hitvā piśācavat / na loke priyatāṃ yāti vyādhibhiś ca na pīḍyate //
column2: He who, disregarding the rule (given above), does not eat meat like a Pisaka, becomes dear to men, and will not be tormented by diseases.

column1: anumantā viśasitā nihantā krayavikrayī / saṃskartā copahartā ca khādakaś ceti ghātakāḥ //
column2: He who permits (the slaughter of an animal), he who cuts it up, he who kills it, he who buys or sells (meat), he who cooks it, he who serves it up, and he who eats it, (must all be considered as) the slayers (of the animal).

column1: svamāṃsaṃ paramāṃsena yo vardhayitum icchati / anabhyarcya pitṝn devāṃs tato 'nyo nāsty apuṇyakṛt //
column2: There is no greater sinner than that (man) who, though not worshipping the gods or the manes, seeks to increase (the bulk of) his own flesh by the flesh of other (beings).

column1: varṣe varṣe 'śvamedhena yo yajeta śataṃ samāḥ / māṃsāni ca na khāded yas tayoḥ puṇyaphalaṃ samam //
column2: He who during a hundred years annually offers a horse-sacrifice, and he who entirely abstains from meat, obtain the same reward for their meritorious (conduct).

column1: phalamūlāśanair medhyair munyannānāṃ ca bhojanaiḥ / na tat phalam avāpnoti yan māṃsaparivarjanāt //
column2: By subsisting on pure fruit and roots, and by eating food fit for ascetics (in the forest), one does not gain (so great) a reward as by entirely avoiding (the use of) flesh.

column1: māṃ sa bhakṣayitāmutra yasya māṃsam ihādmy aham / etan māṃsasya māṃsatvaṃ pravadanti manīṣiṇaḥ //
column2: 'Me he (mam sah)' will devour in the next (world), whose flesh I eat in this (life); the wise declare this (to be) the real meaning of the word 'flesh' (mamsah).

column1: na māṃsabhakṣaṇe doṣo na madye na ca maithune / pravṛttir eṣā bhūtānāṃ nivṛttis tu mahāphalā //
column2: There is no sin in eating meat, in (drinking) spirituous liquor, and in carnal intercourse, for that is the natural way of created beings, but abstention brings great rewards.

column1: pretaśuddhiṃ pravakṣyāmi dravyaśuddhiṃ tathaiva ca / caturṇām api varṇānāṃ yathāvad anupūrvaśaḥ //
column2: I will now in due order explain the purification for the dead and the purification of things as they are prescribed for the four castes (varna).

column1: dantajāte 'nujāte ca kṛtacūḍe ca saṃsthite / aśuddhā bāndhavāḥ sarve sūtake ca tathocyate //
column2: When (a child) dies that has teethed, or that before teething has received (the sacrament of) the tonsure (Kudakarana) or (of the initiation), all relatives (become) impure, and on the birth (of a child) the same (rule) is prescribed.

column1: daśāhaṃ śāvam āśaucaṃ sapiṇḍeṣu vidhīyate / arvāk saṃcayanād asthnāṃ tryaham ekāham eva vā //
column2: It is ordained (that) among Sapindas the impurity on account of a death (shall last) ten days, (or) until the bones have been collected, (or) three days or one day only.

column1: sapiṇḍatā tu puruṣe saptame vinivartate / samānodakabhāvas tu janmanāmnor avedane //
column2: But the Sapinda-relationship ceases with the seventh person (in the ascending and descending lines), the Samanodaka-relationship when the (common) origin and the (existence of a common family)-name are no (longer) known.

column1: yathedaṃ śāvam āśaucaṃ sapiṇḍeṣu vidhīyate / janane 'py evam eva syān nipuṇaṃ śuddhim icchatām //
column2: As this impurity on account of a death is prescribed for (all) Sapindas, even so it shall be (held) on a birth by those who desire to be absolutely pure.

column1: sarveṣāṃ śāvam āśaucaṃ mātāpitros tu sūtakam / sūtakaṃ mātur eva syād upaspṛśya pitā śuciḥ //
column2: (Or while) the impurity on account of a death is common to all (Sapindas), that caused by a birth (falls) on the parents alone; (or) it shall fall on the mother alone, and the father shall become pure by bathing;

column1: nirasya tu pumāñ śukram upaspṛsyaiva śudhyati / baijikād abhisaṃbandhād anurundhyād aghaṃ tryaham //
column2: But a man, having spent his strength, is purified merely by bathing; after begetting a child (on a remarried female), he shall retain the impurity during three days.

column1: ahnā caikena rātryā ca trirātrair eva ca tribhiḥ / śavaspṛśo viśudhyanti tryahād udakadāyinaḥ //
column2: Those who have touched a corpse are purified after one day and night (added to) three periods of three days; those who give libations of water, after three days.

column1: guroḥ pretasya śiṣyas tu pitṛmedhaṃ samācaran / pretahāraiḥ samaṃ tatra daśarātreṇa śudhyati //
column2: A pupil who performs the Pitrimedha for his deceased teacher, becomes also pure after ten days, just like those who carry the corpse out (to the burial-ground).

column1: rātribhir māsatulyābhir garbhasrāve viśudhyati / rajasy uparate sādhvī snānena strī rajasvalā //
column2: (A woman) is purified on a miscarriage in as many (days and) nights as months (elapsed after conception), and a menstruating female becomes pure by bathing after the menstrual secretion has ceased (to flow).

column1: nṛṇām akṛtacūḍānāṃ viśuddhir naiśikī smṛtā / nirvṛttacūḍakānāṃ tu trirātrāc chuddhir iṣyate //
column2: (On the death) of children whose tonsure (Kudakarman) has not been performed, the (Sapindas) are declared to become pure in one (day and) night; (on the death) of those who have received the tonsure (but not the initiation, the law) ordains (that) the purification (takes place) after three days.

column1: ūnadvivārṣikaṃ pretaṃ nidadhyur bāndhavā bahiḥ / alaṃkṛtya śucau bhūmāv asthisaṃcayanād ṛte //
column2: A child that has died before the completion of its second year, the relatives shall carry out (of the village), decked (with flowers, and bury it) in pure ground, without collecting the bones (afterwards).

column1: nāsya kāryo 'gnisaṃskāro na ca kāryodakakriyā / araṇye kāṣṭhavat tyaktvā kṣapeyus tryaham eva tu // nātrivarṣasya kartavyā bāndhavair udakakriyā / jātadantasya vā kuryur nāmni vāpi kṛte sati //
column2: Such (a child) shall not be burnt with fire, and no libations of water shall be offered to it; leaving it like a (log of) wood in the forest, (the relatives) shall remain impure during three days only. The relatives shall not offer libations to (a child) that has not reached the third year; but if it had teeth, or the ceremony of naming it (Namakarman) had been performed, (the offering of water is) optional.

column1: sabrahmacāriṇy ekāham atīte kṣapaṇaṃ smṛtam / janmany ekodakānāṃ tu trirātrāc chuddhir iṣyate //
column2: If a fellow-student has died, the Smriti prescribes an impurity of one day; on a birth the purification of the Samanodakas is declared (to take place) after three (days and) nights.

column1: strīṇām asaṃskṛtānāṃ tu tryahāc chudhyanti bāndhavāḥ / yathoktenaiva kalpena śudhyanti tu sanābhayaḥ //
column2: (On the death) of females (betrothed but) not married (the bridegroom and his) relatives are purified after three days, and the paternal relatives become pure according to the same rule.

column1: akṣāralavaṇānnāḥ syur nimajjeyuś ca te tryaham / māṃsāśanaṃ ca nāśnīyuḥ śayīraṃś ca pṛthak kṣitau //
column2: Let (mourners) eat food without factitious salt, bathe during three days, abstain from meat, and sleep separate on the ground.

column1: saṃnidhāv eṣa vai kalpaḥ śāvāśaucasya kīrtitaḥ / asaṃnidhāv ayaṃ jñeyo vidhiḥ saṃbandhibāndhavaiḥ //
column2: The above rule regarding impurity on account of a death has been prescribed (for cases where the kinsmen live) near (the deceased); (Sapinda) kinsmen and (Samanodaka) relatives must know the following rule (to refer to cases where deceased lived) at a distance (from them).

column1: vigataṃ tu videśasthaṃ śṛṇuyād yo hy anirdaśam / yac cheṣaṃ daśarātrasya tāvad evāśucir bhavet //
column2: He who may hear that (a relative) residing in a distant country has died, before ten (days after his death have elapsed), shall be impure for the remainder of the period of ten (days and) nights only.

column1: atikrānte daśāhe ca trirātram aśucir bhavet / saṃvatsare vyatīte tu spṛṣṭvaivāpo viśudhyati //
column2: If the ten days have passed, he shall be impure during three (days and) nights; but if a year has elapsed (since the occurrence of the death), he becomes pure merely by bathing.

column1: nirdaśaṃ jñātimaraṇaṃ śrutvā putrasya janma ca / savāsā jalam āplutya śuddho bhavati mānavaḥ //
column2: A man who hears of a (Sapinda) relative's death, or of the birth of a son after the ten days (of impurity have passed), becomes pure by bathing, dressed in his garments.

column1: bāle deśāntarasthe ca pṛthakpiṇḍe ca saṃsthite / savāsā jalam āplutya sadya eva viśudhyati //
column2: If an infant (that has not teethed), or a (grownup relative who is) not a Sapinda, die in a distant country, one becomes at once pure after bathing in one's clothes.

column1: antardaśāhe syātāṃ cet punar maraṇajanmanī / tāvat syād aśucir vipro yāvat tat syād anirdaśam //
column2: If within the ten days (of impurity) another birth or death happens, a Brahmana shall remain impure only until the (first) period of ten days has expired.

column1: trirātram āhur āśaucam ācārye saṃsthite sati / tasya putre ca patnyāṃ ca divārātram iti sthitiḥ // śrotriye tūpasaṃpanne trirātram aśucir bhavet / mātule pakṣiṇīṃ rātriṃ śiṣyartvigbāndhaveṣu ca //
column2: They declare that, when the teacher (akarya) has died, the impurity (lasts) three days; if the (teacher's) son or wife (is dead, it lasts) a day and a night; that is a settled (rule). For a Srotriya who resides with (him out of affection), a man shall be impure for three days; for a maternal uncle, a pupil, an officiating priest, or a maternal relative, for one night together with the preceding and following days.

column1: prete rājani sajyotir yasya syād viṣaye sthitaḥ / aśrotriye tv ahaḥ kṛtsnam anūcāne tathā gurau //
column2: If the king in whose realm he resides is dead, (he shall be impure) as long as the light (of the sun or stars shines), but for (an intimate friend) who is not a Srotriya (the impurity lasts) for a whole day, likewise for a Guru who knows the Veda and the Angas.

column1: śuddhyed vipro daśāhena dvādaśāhena bhūmipaḥ / vaiśyaḥ pañcadaśāhena śūdro māsena śudhyati //
column2: A Brahmana shall be pure after ten days, a Kshatriya after twelve, a Vaisya after fifteen, and a Sudra is purified after a month.

column1: na vardhayed aghāhāni pratyūhen nāgniṣu kriyāḥ / na ca tatkarma kurvāṇaḥ sanābhyo 'py aśucir bhavet //
column2: Let him not (unnecessarily) lengthen the period of impurity, nor interrupt the rites to be performed with the sacred fires; for he who performs that (Agnihotra) rite will not be impure, though (he be) a (Sapinda) relative.

column1: divākīrtim udakyāṃ ca patitaṃ sūtikāṃ tathā / śavaṃ tatspṛṣṭinaṃ caiva spṛṣṭvā snānena śudhyati //
column2: When he has touched a Kandala, a menstruating woman, an outcast, a woman in childbed, a corpse, or one who has touched a (corpse), he becomes pure by bathing.

column1: ācamya prayato nityaṃ japed aśucidarśane / saurān mantrān yathotsāhaṃ pāvamānīś ca śaktitaḥ //
column2: He who has purified himself by sipping water shall, on seeing any impure (thing or person), always mutter the sacred texts, addressed to Surya, and the Pavamani (verses).

column1: nāraṃ spṛṣṭvāsthi sasnehaṃ snātvā vipro viśudhyati / ācamyaiva tu niḥsnehaṃ gām ālabhyārkam īkṣya vā //
column2: A Brahmana who has touched a human bone to which fat adheres, becomes pure by bathing; if it be free from fat, by sipping water and by touching (afterwards) a cow or looking at the sun.

column1: ādiṣṭī nodakaṃ kuryād ā vratasya samāpanāt / samāpte tūdakaṃ kṛtvā trirātreṇaiva śudhyati //
column2: He who has undertaken the performance of a vow shall not pour out libations (to the dead) until the vow has been completed; but when he has offered water after its completion, he becomes pure in three days only.

column1: vṛthāsaṃkarajātānāṃ pravrajyāsu ca tiṣṭhatām / ātmanas tyāgināṃ caiva nivartetodakakriyā // pāṣaṇḍam āśritānāṃ ca carantīnāṃ ca kāmataḥ / garbhabhartṛdruhāṃ caiva surāpīnāṃ ca yoṣitām //
column2: Libations of water shall not be offered to those who (neglect the prescribed rites and may be said to) have been born in vain, to those born in consequence of an illegal mixture of the castes, to those who are ascetics (of heretical sects), and to those who have committed suicide, To women who have joined a heretical sect, who through lust live (with many men), who have caused an abortion, have killed their husbands, or drink spirituous liquor.

column1: ācāryaṃ svam upādhyāyaṃ pitaraṃ mātaraṃ gurum / nirhṛtya tu vratī pretān na vratena viyujyate //
column2: A student does not break his vow by carrying out (to the place of cremation) his own dead teacher (akarya), sub-teacher (upadhyaya), father, mother, or Guru.

column1: dakṣiṇena mṛtaṃ śūdraṃ puradvāreṇa nirharet / paścimottarapūrvais tu yathāyogaṃ dvijanmanaḥ //
column2: Let him carry out a dead Sudra by the southern gate of the town, but (the corpses of) twice-born men, as is proper, by the western, northern, or eastern (gates).

column1: na rājñām aghadoṣo 'sti vratināṃ na ca sattriṇām / aindraṃ sthānam upāsīnā brahmabhūtā hi te sadā //
column2: The taint of impurity does not fall on kings, and those engaged in the performance of a vow, or of a Sattra; for the (first are) seated on the throne of Indra, and the (last two are) ever pure like Brahman.

column1: rājño mahātmike sthāne sadyaḥśaucaṃ vidhīyate / prajānāṃ parirakṣārtham āsanaṃ cātra kāraṇam //
column2: For a king, on the throne of magnanimity, immediate purification is prescribed, and the reason for that is that he is seated (there) for the protection of (his) subjects.

column1: ḍimbhāhavahatānāṃ ca vidyutā pārthivena ca / gobrāhmaṇasya caivārthe yasya cecchati pārthivaḥ //
column2: (The same rule applies to the kinsmen) of those who have fallen in a riot or a battle, (of those who have been killed) by lightning or by the king, and (of those who perished fighting) for cows and Brahmanas, and to those whom the king wishes (to be pure).

column1: somāgnyarkānilendrāṇāṃ vittāppatyor yamasya ca / aṣṭānāṃ lokapālānāṃ vapur dhārayate nṛpaḥ //
column2: A king is an incarnation of the eight guardian deities of the world, the Moon, the Fire, the Sun, the Wind, Indra, the Lords of wealth and water (Kubera and Varuna), and Yama.

column1: lokeśādhiṣṭhito rājā nāsyāśaucaṃ vidhīyate / śaucāśaucaṃ hi martyānāṃ lokebhyaḥ prabhavāpyayau //
column2: Because the king is pervaded by those lords of the world, no impurity is ordained for him; for purity and impurity of mortals is caused and removed by (those) lords of the world.

column1: udyatair āhave śastraiḥ kṣatradharmahatasya ca / sadyaḥ saṃtiṣṭhate yajñas tathāśaucam iti sthitiḥ //
column2: By him who is slain in battle with brandished weapons according to the law of the Kshatriyas, a (Srauta) sacrifice is instantly completed, and so is the period of impurity (caused by his death); that is a settled rule.

column1: vipraḥ śudhyaty apaḥ spṛṣṭvā kṣatriyo vāhanāyudham / vaiśyaḥ pratodaṃ raśmīn vā yaṣṭiṃ śūdraḥ kṛtakriyaḥ //
column2: (At the end of the period of impurity) a Brahmana who has performed the necessary rites, becomes pure by touching water, a Kshatriya by touching the animal on which he rides, and his weapons, a Vaisya by touching his goad or the nose-string (of his oxen), a Sudra by touching his staff.

column1: etad vo 'bhihitaṃ śaucaṃ sapiṇḍeṣu dvijottamāḥ / asapiṇḍeṣu sarveṣu pretaśuddhiṃ nibodhata //
column2: Thus the purification (required) on (the death of) Sapindas has been explained to you, O best of twice-born men; hear now the manner in which men are purified on the death of any (relative who is) not a Sapinda.

column1: asapiṇḍaṃ dvijaṃ pretaṃ vipro nirhṛtya bandhuvat / viśudhyati trirātreṇa mātur āptāṃś ca bāndhavān //
column2: A Brahmana, having carried out a dead Brahmana who is not a Sapinda, as (if he were) a (near) relative, or a near relative of his mother, becomes pure after three days;

column1: yady annam atti teṣāṃ tu daśāhenaiva śudhyati / anadann annam ahnaiva na cet tasmin gṛhe vaset //
column2: But if he eats the food of the (Sapindas of the deceased), he is purified in ten days, (but) in one day, if he does not eat their food nor dwells in their house.

column1: anugamyecchayā pretaṃ jñātim ajñātim eva ca / snātvā sacailaḥ spṛṣṭvāgniṃ ghṛtaṃ prāśya viśudhyati //
column2: Having voluntarily followed a corpse, whether (that of) a paternal kinsman or (of) a stranger, he becomes pure by bathing, dressed in his clothes, by touching fire and eating clarified butter.

column1: na vipraṃ sveṣu tiṣṭhatsu mṛtaṃ śūdreṇa nāyayet / asvargyā hy āhutiḥ sā syāc chūdrasaṃsparśadūṣitā //
column2: Let him not allow a dead Brahmana to be carried out by a Sudra, while men of the same caste are at hand; for that burnt-offering which is defiled by a Sudra's touch is detrimental to (the deceased's passage to) heaven.

column1: jñānaṃ tapo 'gnir āhāro mṛn mano vāry upāñjanam / vāyuḥ karmārkakālau ca śuddheḥ kartṝṇi dehinām //
column2: The knowledge (of Brahman) austerities, fire, (holy) food, earth, (restraint of) the internal organ, water, smearing (with cowdung), the wind, sacred rites, the sun, and time are the purifiers of corporeal (beings).

column1: sarveṣām eva śaucānām arthaśaucaṃ paraṃ smṛtaṃ / yo 'rthe śucir hi sa śucir na mṛdvāriśuciḥ śuciḥ //
column2: Among all modes of purification, purity in (the acquisition of) wealth is declared to be the best; for he is pure who gains wealth with clean hands, not he who purifies himself with earth and water.

column1: kṣāntyā śudhyanti vidvāṃso dānenākāryakāriṇaḥ / pracchannapāpā japyena tapasā vedavittamāḥ //
column2: The learned are purified by a forgiving disposition, those who have committed forbidden actions by liberality, secret sinners by muttering (sacred texts), and those who best know the Veda by austerities.

column1: mṛttoyaiḥ śudhyate śodhyaṃ nadī vegena śudhyati / rajasā strī manoduṣṭā saṃnyāsena dvijottamāḥ //
column2: By earth and water is purified what ought to be made pure, a river by its current, a woman whose thoughts have been impure by the menstrual secretion, a Brahmana by abandoning the world (samnyasa).

column1: adbhir gātrāṇi śudhyanti manaḥ satyena śudhyati / vidyātapobhyāṃ bhūtātmā buddhir jñānena śudhyati //
column2: The body is cleansed by water, the internal organ is purified by truthfulness, the individual soul by sacred learning and austerities, the intellect by (true) knowledge.

column1: eṣa śaucasya vaḥ proktaḥ śarīrasya vinirṇayaḥ / nānāvidhānāṃ dravyāṇāṃ śuddheḥ śṛṇuta nirṇayam //
column2: Thus the precise rules for the purification of the body have been declared to you; hear now the decision (of the law) regarding the purification of the various (inanimate) things.

column1: taijasānāṃ maṇīnāṃ ca sarvasyāśmamayasya ca / bhasmanādbhir mṛdā caiva śuddhir uktā manīṣibhiḥ //
column2: The wise ordain that all (objects) made of metal, gems, and anything made of stone are to be cleansed with ashes, earth, and water.

column1: nirlepaṃ kāñcanaṃ bhāṇḍam adbhir eva viśudhyati / abjam aśmamayaṃ caiva rājataṃ cānupaskṛtam //
column2: A golden vessel which shows no stains, becomes pure with water alone, likewise what is produced in water (as shells and coral), what is made of stone, and a silver (vessel) not enchased.

column1: apām agneś ca saṃyogād dhaimaṃ raupyaṃ ca nirbabhau / tasmāt tayoḥ svayonyaiva nirṇeko guṇavattaraḥ //
column2: From the union of water and fire arose the glittering gold and silver; those two, therefore, are best purified by (the elements) from which they sprang.

column1: tāmrāyaḥkāṃsyaraityānāṃ trapuṇaḥ sīsakasya ca / śaucaṃ yathārhaṃ kartavyaṃ kṣārāmlodakavāribhiḥ // dravāṇāṃ caiva sarveṣāṃ śuddhir utpavanaṃ smṛtam / prokṣaṇaṃ saṃhatānāṃ ca dāravāṇāṃ ca takṣaṇam //
column2: Copper, iron, brass, pewter, tin, and lead must be cleansed, as may be suitable (for each particular case), by alkaline (substances), acids or water. The purification prescribed for all (sorts of) liquids is by passing two blades of Kusa grass through them, for solid things by sprinkling (them with water), for (objects) made of wood by planing them.

column1: mārjanaṃ yajñapātrāṇāṃ pāṇinā yajñakarmaṇi / camasānāṃ grahāṇāṃ ca śuddhiḥ prakṣālanena tu //
column2: At sacrifices the purification of (the Soma cups called) Kamasas and Grahas, and of (other) sacrificial vessels (takes place) by rubbing (them) with the hand, and (afterwards) rinsing (them with water).

column1: carūṇāṃ sruksruvāṇāṃ ca śuddhir uṣṇena vāriṇā / sphyaśūrpaśakaṭānāṃ ca musalolūkhalasya ca //
column2: The Karu and (the spoons called) Sruk and Sruva must be cleaned with hot water, likewise (the wooden sword, called) Sphya, the winnowing-basket (Surpa), the cart (for bringing the grain), the pestle and the mortar.

column1: adbhis tu prokṣaṇaṃ śaucaṃ bahūnāṃ dhānyavāsasām / prakṣālanena tv alpānām adbhiḥ śaucaṃ vidhīyate //
column2: The manner of purifying large quantities of grain and of cloth is to sprinkle them with water; but the purification of small quantities is prescribed (to take place) by washing them.

column1: cailavac carmaṇāṃ śuddhir vaidalānāṃ tathaiva ca / śākamūlaphalānāṃ ca dhānyavac chuddhir iṣyate // kauśeyāvikayor ūṣaiḥ kutapānām ariṣṭakaiḥ / śrīphalair aṃśupaṭṭānāṃ kṣaumāṇāṃ gaurasarṣapaiḥ //
column2: Skins and (objects) made of split cane must be cleaned like clothes; vegetables, roots, and fruit like grain; Silk and woollen stuffs with alkaline earth; blankets with pounded Arishta (fruit); Amsupattas with Bel fruit; linen cloth with (a paste of) yellow mustard.

column1: kṣaumavac chaṅkhaśṛṅgāṇām asthidantamayasya ca / śuddhir vijānatā kāryā gomūtreṇodakena vā // prokṣaṇāt tṛṇakāṣṭhaṃ ca palālaṃ caiva śudhyati / mārjanopāñjanair veśma punaḥpākena mṛnmayam //
column2: A man who knows (the law) must purify conch-shells, horn, bone and ivory, like linen cloth, or with a mixture of cow's urine and water. Grass, wood, and straw become pure by being sprinkled (with water), a house by sweeping and smearing (it with cowdung or whitewash), an earthen (vessel) by a second burning.

column1: madyair mūtraiḥ purīṣair vā ṣṭhīvanaih pūyaśoṇitaiḥ / saṃspṛṣṭaṃ naiva śuddhyeta punaḥpākena mṛnmayam //
column2: An earthen vessel which has been defiled by spirituous liquor, urine, ordure, saliva, pus or blood cannot be purified by another burning.

column1: saṃmārjanopāñjanena sekenollekhanena ca / gavāṃ ca parivāsena bhūmiḥ śudhyati pañcabhiḥ //
column2: Land is purified by (the following) five (modes, viz.) by sweeping, by smearing (it with cowdung), by sprinkling (it with cows' urine or milk), by scraping, and by cows staying (on it during a day and night).

column1: pakṣijagdhaṃ gavā ghrātam avadhūtam avakṣutam / dūṣitaṃ keśakīṭaiś ca mṛtprakṣepeṇa śudhyati //
column2: (Food) which has been pecked at by birds, smelt at by cows, touched (with the foot), sneezed on, or defiled by hair or insects, becomes pure by scattering earth (over it).

column1: yāvan nāpaity amedhyāktād gandho lepaś ca tatkṛtaḥ / tāvan mṛdvāri cādeyaṃ sarvāsu dravyaśuddhiṣu //
column2: As long as the (foul) smell does not leave an (object) defiled by impure substances, and the stain caused by them (does not disappear), so long must earth and water be applied in cleansing (inanimate) things.

column1: trīṇi devāḥ pavitrāṇi brāhmaṇānām akalpayan / adṛṣṭam adbhir nirṇiktaṃ yac ca vācā praśasyate //
column2: The gods declared three things (to be) pure to Brahmanas, that (on which) no (taint is) visible, what has been washed with water, and what has been commended (as pure) by the word (of a Brahmana).

column1: āpaḥ śuddhā bhūmigatā vaitṛṣṇyaṃ yāsu gor bhavet / avyāptāś ced amedhyena gandhavarṇarasānvitāḥ //
column2: Water, sufficient (in quantity) in order to slake the thirst of a cow, possessing the (proper) smell, colour, and taste, and unmixed with impure substances, is pure, if it is collected on (pure) ground.

column1: nityaṃ śuddhaḥ kāruhastaḥ paṇye yac ca prasāritam / brahmacārigataṃ bhaikṣyaṃ nityaṃ medhyam iti sthitiḥ //
column2: The hand of an artisan is always pure, so is (every vendible commodity) exposed for sale in the market, and food obtained by begging which a student holds (in his hand) is always fit for use; that is a settled rule.

column1: nityam āsyaṃ śuci strīṇāṃ śakuniḥ phalapātane / prasrave ca śucir vatsaḥ śvā mṛgagrahaṇe śuciḥ //
column2: The mouth of a woman is always pure, likewise a bird when he causes a fruit to fall; a calf is pure on the flowing of the milk, and a dog when he catches a deer.

column1: śvabhir hatasya yan māṃsaṃ śuci tan manur abravīt / kravyādbhiś ca hatasyānyaiś caṇḍālādyaiś ca dasyubhiḥ //
column2: Manu has declared that the flesh (of an animal) killed by dogs is pure, likewise (that) of a (beast) slain by carnivorous (animals) or by men of low caste (Dasyu), such as Kandalas.

column1: ūrdhvaṃ nābher yāni khāni tāni medhyāni sarvaśaḥ / yāny adhas tāny amedhyāni dehāc caiva malāś cyutāḥ //
column2: All those cavities (of the body) which lie above the navel are pure, (but) those which are below the navel are impure, as well as excretions that fall from the body.

column1: makṣikā vipruṣaś chāyā gaur aśvaḥ sūryaraśmayaḥ / rajo bhūr vāyur agniś ca sparśe medhyāni nirdiśet //
column2: Flies, drops of water, a shadow, a cow, a horse, the rays of the sun, dust, earth, the wind, and fire one must know to be pure to the touch.

column1: viṇmūtrotsargaśuddhyarthaṃ mṛdvāry ādeyam arthavat / daihikānāṃ malānāṃ ca śuddhiṣu dvādaśasv api //
column2: In order to cleanse (the organs) by which urine and faeces are ejected, earth and water must be used, as they may be required, likewise in removing the (remaining ones among) twelve impurities of the body.

column1: vasā śukram asṛṅ majjā mūtraviṭ ghrāṇakarṇaviṭ / śleśma aśru dūṣikā svedo dvādaśaite nṛṇāṃ malāḥ //
column2: Oily exudations, semen, blood, (the fatty substance of the) brain, urine, faeces, the mucus of the nose, ear-wax, phlegm, tears, the rheum of the eyes, and sweat are the twelve impurities of human (bodies).

column1: ekā liṅge gude tisras tathaikatra kare daśa / ubhayoḥ sapta dātavyā mṛdaḥ śuddhim abhīpsatā //
column2: He who desires to be pure, must clean the organ by one (application of) earth, the anus by (applying earth) three (times), the (left) hand alone by (applying it) ten (times), and both (hands) by (applying it) seven (times).

column1: etac chaucaṃ gṛhasthānāṃ dviguṇaṃ brahmacāriṇām / triguṇaṃ syād vanasthānāṃ yatīnāṃ tu caturguṇam //
column2: Such is the purification ordained for householders; (it shall be) double for students, treble for hermits, but quadruple for ascetics.

column1: kṛtvā mūtraṃ purīṣaṃ vā khāny ācānta upaspṛśet / vedam adhyeṣyamāṇaś ca annam aśnaṃś ca sarvadā //
column2: When he has voided urine or faeces, let him, after sipping water, sprinkle the cavities, likewise when he is going to recite the Veda, and always before he takes food.

column1: trir ācāmed apaḥ pūrvaṃ dviḥ pramṛjyāt tato mukham / śarīraṃ śaucam icchan hi strī śūdras tu sakṛt sakṛt //
column2: Let him who desires bodily purity first sip water three times, and then twice wipe his mouth; but a woman and a Sudra (shall perform each act) once (only).

column1: śūdrāṇāṃ māsikaṃ kāryaṃ vapanaṃ nyāyavartinām / vaiśyavac chaucakalpaś ca dvijocchiṣṭaṃ ca bhojanam //
column2: Sudras who live according to the law, shall each month shave (their heads); their mode of purification (shall be) the same as that of Vaisyas, and their food the fragments of an Aryan's meal.

column1: nocchiṣṭaṃ kurvate mukhyā vipruṣo 'ṅgaṃ na yānti yāḥ / na śmaśrūṇi gatāny āsyaṃ na dantāntaradhiṣṭhitam //
column2: Drops (of water) from the mouth which do not fall on a limb, do not make (a man) impure, nor the hair of the moustache entering the mouth, nor what adheres to the teeth.

column1: spṛśanti bindavaḥ pādau ya ācāmayataḥ parān / bhaumikais te samā jñeyā na tair āprayato bhavet //
column2: Drops which trickle on the feet of him who offers water for sipping to others, must be considered as equal to (water collected on the ground; they render him not impure.

column1: ucchiṣṭena tu saṃspṛṣṭo dravyahastaḥ kathaṃ cana / anidhāyaiva tad dravyam ācāntaḥ śucitām iyāt //
column2: He who, while carrying anything in any manner, is touched by an impure (person or thing), shall become pure, if he performs an ablution, without putting down that object.

column1: vānto viriktaḥ snātvā tu ghṛtaprāśanam ācaret / ācāmed eva bhuktvānnaṃ snānaṃ maithuninaḥ smṛtam // suptvā kṣutvā ca bhuktvā ca niṣṭhīvyoktvānṛtāni ca / pītvāpo 'dhyeṣyamāṇaś ca ācāmet prayato 'pi san //
column2: He who has vomited or purged shall bathe, and afterwards eat clarified butter; but if (the attack comes on) after he has eaten, let him only sip water; bathing is prescribed for him who has had intercourse with a woman. Though he may be (already) pure, let him sip water after sleeping, sneezing, eating, spitting, telling untruths, and drinking water, likewise when he is going to study the Veda.

column1: eṣāṃ śaucavidhiḥ kṛtsno dravyaśuddhis tathaiva ca / ukto vaḥ sarvavarṇānāṃ strīṇāṃ dharmān nibodhata //
column2: Thus the rules of personal purification for men of all castes, and those for cleaning (inanimate) things, have been fully declared to you: hear now the duties of women.

column1: bālayā vā yuvatyā vā vṛddhayā vāpi yoṣitā / na svātantryeṇa kartavyaṃ kiṃ cid kāryaṃ gṛheṣv api //
column2: By a girl, by a young woman, or even by an aged one, nothing must be done independently, even in her own house.

column1: bālye pitur vaśe tiṣṭhet pāṇigrāhasya yauvane / putrāṇāṃ bhartari prete na bhajet strī svatantratām // pitrā bhartrā sutair vāpi necched viraham ātmanaḥ / eṣāṃ hi viraheṇa strī garhye kuryād ubhe kule //
column2: In childhood a female must be subject to her father, in youth to her husband, when her lord is dead to her sons; a woman must never be independent. She must not seek to separate herself from her father, husband, or sons; by leaving them she would make both (her own and her husband's) families contemptible.

column1: sadā prahṛṣṭayā bhāvyaṃ gṛhakārye ca dakṣayā / susaṃskṛtopaskarayā vyaye cāmuktahastayā //
column2: She must always be cheerful, clever in (the management of her) household affairs, careful in cleaning her utensils, and economical in expenditure.

column1: yasmai dadyāt pitā tv enāṃ bhrātā vānumate pituḥ / taṃ śuśrūṣeta jīvantaṃ saṃsthitaṃ ca na laṅghayet //
column2: Him to whom her father may give her, or her brother with the father's permission, she shall obey as long as he lives, and when he is dead, she must not insult (his memory).

column1: maṅgalārthaṃ svastyayanaṃ yajñaś cāsāṃ prajāpateḥ / prayujyate vivāhe tu pradānaṃ svāmyakāraṇam //
column2: For the sake of procuring good fortune to (brides), the recitation of benedictory texts (svastyayana), and the sacrifice to the Lord of creatures (Pragapati) are used at weddings; (but) the betrothal (by the father or guardian) is the cause of (the husband's) dominion (over his wife).

column1: anṛtāv ṛtukāle ca mantrasaṃskārakṛt patiḥ / sukhasya nityaṃ dāteha paraloke ca yoṣitaḥ //
column2: The husband who wedded her with sacred texts, always gives happiness to his wife, both in season and out of season, in this world and in the next.

column1: viśīlaḥ kāmavṛtto vā guṇair vā parivarjitaḥ / upacāryaḥ striyā sādhvyā satataṃ devavat patiḥ //
column2: Though destitute of virtue, or seeking pleasure (elsewhere), or devoid of good qualities, (yet) a husband must be constantly worshipped as a god by a faithful wife.

column1: nāsti strīṇāṃ pṛthag yajño na vrataṃ nāpy upoṣaṇam / patiṃ śuśrūṣate yena tena svarge mahīyate //
column2: No sacrifice, no vow, no fast must be performed by women apart (from their husbands); if a wife obeys her husband, she will for that (reason alone) be exalted in heaven.

column1: pāṇigrāhasya sādhvī strī jīvato vā mṛtasya vā / patilokam abhīpsantī nācaret kiṃ cid apriyam //
column2: A faithful wife, who desires to dwell (after death) with her husband, must never do anything that might displease him who took her hand, whether he be alive or dead.

column1: kāmaṃ tu ksapayed dehaṃ puṣpamūlaphalaiḥ śubhaiḥ / na tu nāmāpi gṛhṇīyāt patyau prete parasya tu //
column2: At her pleasure let her emaciate her body by (living on) pure flowers, roots, and fruit; but she must never even mention the name of another man after her husband has died.

column1: āsītā maraṇāt ksāntā niyatā brahmacāriṇī / yo dharma ekapatnīnāṃ kāṅkṣantī tam anuttamam //
column2: Until death let her be patient (of hardships), self-controlled, and chaste, and strive (to fulfil) that most excellent duty which (is prescribed) for wives who have one husband only.

column1: anekāni sahasrāṇi kumārabrahmacāriṇām / divaṃ gatāni viprāṇām akṛtvā kulasaṃtatim //
column2: Many thousands of Brahmanas who were chaste from their youth, have gone to heaven without continuing their race.

column1: mṛte bhartari sāḍhvī strī brahmacarye vyavasthitā / svargaṃ gacchaty aputrāpi yathā te brahmacāriṇaḥ // apatyalobhād yā tu strī bhartāram ativartate / seha nindām avāpnoti paralokāc ca hīyate //
column2: A virtuous wife who after the death of her husband constantly remains chaste, reaches heaven, though she have no son, just like those chaste men. But a woman who from a desire to have offspring violates her duty towards her (deceased) husband, brings on herself disgrace in this world, and loses her place with her husband (in heaven).

column1: nānyotpannā prajāstīha na cāpy anyaparigrahe / na dvitīyaś ca sādhvīnāṃ kva cid bhartopadiśyate //
column2: Offspring begotten by another man is here not (considered lawful), nor (does offspring begotten) on another man's wife (belong to the begetter), nor is a second husband anywhere prescribed for virtuous women.

column1: patiṃ hitvāpakṛṣṭaṃ svam utkṛṣṭaṃ yā niṣevate / nindyaiva sā bhavel loke parapūrveti cocyate //
column2: She who cohabits with a man of higher caste, forsaking her own husband who belongs to a lower one, will become contemptible in this world, and is called a remarried woman (parapurva).

column1: vyabhicārāt tu bhartuḥ strī loke prāpnoti nindyatām / śṛgālayoniṃ prāpnoti pāparogaiś ca pīḍyate //
column2: By violating her duty towards her husband, a wife is disgraced in this world, (after death) she enters the womb of a jackal, and is tormented by diseases (the punishment of) her sin.
